The flag of Comoros was created in 2002.

[[Selma, Switzerland]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Graubünden

Selma  used to be a municipality of the district Moesa in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.  On 1 January 2015 the municipalities of Arvigo, Braggio, Cauco and Selma combined and became the new municipality of Calanca.

[[Rimbach-près-Masevaux]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Rimbach-près-Masevaux is a commune in the Haut-Rhin department of east France.

The villages of Basse Bers, Ermensbach, Grossenberg, Haute Bers, Horben, Johannesberg, Langmatt, Neuerbet, Riedelsbourg, Riesenwald and Ruchberg are in this commune.

[[Calanca, Switzerland]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Graubünden, 2015 establishments in Switzerland

Calanca is a municipality of the district of Moesa in the Swiss canton of Graubünden.  On 1 January 2015 the former municipalities of Arvigo, Braggio, Cauco and Selma merged to form the new municipality of Calanca.

[[Flag of Tanzania]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Tanzania

The flag of Tanzania has a yellow-fimbriated black diagonal band, divided diagonally from the lower hoist-side corner, with a green upper triangle and blue lower triangle.

[[Bình Dương]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Vietnam

Bình Dương is a province in the Southeast region of Vietnam. Bình Dương's current capital is Thủ Dầu Một the seventh largest province in the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

Bình Dương has traditional villages, such as wood carving, pottery and lacquer painting. Since ancient times, art pottery, lacquerware and sculpture of Bình Dương have participated in international fairs and also exported to France and many countries in the region.

When the August Revolution broke out, the province commissioned a general uprising to seize power in Bình Dương and establish a provincial People's Committee. In mid-September, the provincial People's Committee changed its name to the Provincial Resistance Administrative Committee. At the end of September 1945, the British-French alliance opened fire to recapture the South. The Democratic Republic of Vietnam in South Vietnam decides the South resistance. Implementing the policy of "dissolving" of the Communist Party of Vietnam. On 11 November 1945 the provincial Party Committee also proceeded to "dissolve", actually developing the revolutionary movement under the name Việt Minh.

[[2018 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic hurricane seasons

The 2018 Atlantic hurricane season was a near-normal season but above-average in terms of ACE and it had 15 named storms, 8 hurricanes, and 2 major hurricanes in which tropical cyclones were formed in the Northern Hemisphere at the Atlantic basin. It happens yearly, and the hurricane season officially started on June 1, and officially ended on November 30.

Subtropical Storm Alberto in late May was the first storm of the season that formed on May 25. This was the fourth consecutive season in which storms form before the official start of the hurricane season. Beryl became the first hurricane of the season in early July. Florence became the first major hurricane of the season on September 5. Michael became the second major hurricane of the season on October 9, and a day later, it became the third-most intense hurricane to make landfall in the United States in terms of pressure, behind the 1935 Labor Day hurricane and Hurricane Camille of 1969. As Michael became a Category 5, 2018 became a third consecutive season to feature at least one Category 5 hurricane (Matthew in 2016; Irma and Maria in 2017). This season is the first on record to see seven storms that were subtropical at some point in their lifetimes (Alberto, Beryl, Debby, Ernesto, Joyce, Leslie, and Oscar). The season ended with Hurricane Oscar on October 31.

[[Dawood Sarkhosh]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1971 births, Hazara people

Dawood Sarkhosh is a singer, songwriter and poet from Afghanistan. 

He makes most of his songs himself.

Dawood Sarkhosh has held many concerts in various countries such as Australia, Russia, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Pakistan and Iran.

[[Rajanpur]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in India

Rajanpur (Urdu: راجن پُور‬‎), is a capital city of Rajanpur District in Punjab, Pakistan. The district is located west of the Indus River.

[[Miandam]]

CATEGORIES: Hill Stations in Pakistan

Miandam is a hill station and tourist place in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. It lies 1800 above sea level.

[[Leona Helmsley]]

CATEGORIES: Deaths from cardiovascular disease, American fraudsters, 1920 births, 2007 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States

Leona Helmsley (July 4, 1920 – August 20, 2007) was an American businesswoman. She was known for having a flamboyant personality. She had a reputation for tyrannical behavior; she was nicknamed the Queen of Mean.

She owned many hotels, apartment buildings and condominiums.

Helmsley was found guilty in 1989 of tax evasion, false personal tax returns and mail fraud. She served some time in prison for the crimes.

Helmsley was born in Marbletown, New York. She died from heart failure at age 87 in Greenwich, Connecticut.

[[Jack Ketchum]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cancer deaths in New York City, American novelists, Writers from New Jersey, Screenwriters from New Jersey, People from Livingston, New Jersey

Dallas Mayr (November 10, 1946 – January 24, 2018), better known by his pseudonym Jack Ketchum, was an American author and screenwriter. He was born in Livingston, New Jersey. He was best known for writing the 1989 crime novel The Girl Next Door.

Many of his novels have been made to movies, including Red and The Woman. In 2011, Ketchum received the World Horror Convention Grand Master Award for outstanding contribution to the horror genre.

Ketchum died on January 24, 2018 in New York City of pancreatic cancer at the age of 71.

[[Billy Hancock]]

CATEGORIES: Musicians from Washington, D.C., Singers from Washington, D.C., American rock guitarists, American rock singers, American blues musicians, American jazz musicians, American country guitarists, American country singers, Deaths from cirrhosis, Disease-related deaths in Maryland, 1946 births, 2018 deaths

William C. Hancock Jr. (known as Billy Hancock) (November 4, 1946 – January 22, 2018) was an American singer, guitarist, bassist and multi-instrumental recording artist. He has made many recordings, primarily in the rockabilly genre but also has a large body of recorded work in rock 'n' roll, blues, jazz, rhythm & blues, and country music. He was known for his songs "Shakin' That Rockabilly Fever" and "Wanted: True Rock 'n' Roll".

Hancock died in La Plata, Maryland on January 22, 2018 of complications from cirrhosis at the age of 71.

[[Chartchai Chionoi]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, People with Parkinson's disease, Thai sportspeople, Boxers, People from Bangkok

Chartchai Chionoi (ชาติชาย เชี่ยวน้อย; Chatchai Chiao-noi) a.k.a. Chartchai Laemfapha (ชาติชาย แหลมฟ้าผ่า; Chatchai Laemfapha) or birth name Naris Chionoi (นริศ เชี่ยวน้อย; Narit Chiao-noi; October 10, 1942 – January 21, 2018) was a former professional Thai boxer, WBC World champion & WBA World champion in the flyweight division.  Chionoi took the WBC World Flyweight Title two successive times and the WBA Title one successive times before finally relinquishing it. He was born near Hua Lamphong Station, Pathum Wan District, Bangkok.

Chionoi died on January 21, 2018 of pneumonia complicated from Parkinson's disease in Bangkok at the age of 75.

[[Phil Bredesen]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Governors of Tennessee, Politicians from New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey, Businesspeople from New Jersey, Writers from Tennessee, Mayors of Nashville, Tennessee, US Democratic Party politicians

Philip Norman Bredesen Jr. (born November 21, 1943) is an American politician, author and entrepreneur. He served as the 48th Governor of Tennessee from 2003 to 2011. He is a member of the Democratic Party. He was first elected in 2002 with 50.6% of the vote, and was reelected in 2006 with 68.0%. He served as the 66th Mayor of Nashville from 1991 to 1999.

On December 6, 2017, Bredesen announced he would run for Bob Corker's open seat in the United States Senate, as Corker announced he would not seek reelection in 2018. In August 2018, he became the Democratic nominee. He lost the election to Marsha Blackburn.

[[Richard Fulton]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2018 deaths, United States representatives from Tennessee, Mayors of Nashville, Tennessee, US Democratic Party politicians

Richard Harmon "Dick" Fulton (January 27, 1927 – November 28, 2018) was a Democratic politician. He served as a member of the Tennessee State Senate and of the United States House of Representatives, and the second mayor of the Metropolitan Government of Nashville, Tennessee.

Fulton died on November 28, 2018 under hospice care in Nashville at the age of 91.

[[Marilyn Lloyd]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Infectious disease deaths in Tennessee, United States representatives from Tennessee, Businesspeople from Tennessee, Businesspeople from Arkansas, Politicians from Arkansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Rachel Marilyn Lloyd (née Laird; January 3, 1929 – September 19, 2018) was an American businesswoman and politician. She served for ten terms as member of the United States House of Representatives serving from 1975 to 1995.

Lloyd died on September 19, 2018 in Chattanooga, Tennessee from complications of pneumonia at the age of 89.

[[Robert Lowie]]

CATEGORIES: 1883 births, 1957 deaths, American anthropologists

Robert Harry Lowie (born Robert Heinrich Löwe; June 12, 1883 – September 21, 1957) was an Austrian-born American anthropologist.

[[McKayla Maroney]]

CATEGORIES: American Olympic silver medalists, American Olympic gold medalists, American gymnasts, Sportspeople from California, 1995 births, Living people

McKayla Rose Maroney (born December 9, 1995) is a retired American artistic gymnast and singer. She won several gold medals during her career. She was a member of the American women's gymnastics team, called the Fierce Five, at the 2012 Summer Olympics. She won a gold medal at these Olympic Games. She also won gold medals at the 2011 World Championships and the 2013 World Championships.

In 2012, Maroney won the silver medal in the vault finals. She wasn't happy with the winning. In one photograph, her lips were toward the left side of her face. Then-President Barack Obama copied the pose in November 2012.

In 2016, Maroney retired from competitive gymnastics.

Maroney was born in Aliso Viejo, California.

[[Saulieu]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Côte-d'Or

Saulieu, Burgundian: Saûyeu, is a commune in the arrondissement of Montbard in the Côte-d'Or department in eastern France. It is the capital of the Morvan Region.

About 2,500 people were living in Saulieu in 2015.

[[Tere Liye]]

CATEGORIES: Hindi-language television series, 2010 television series debuts, 2010 establishments in Asia, 2010s establishments in India, 2011 television series endings, 2010s disestablishments in India

Tere Liye is a Hindi-language Indian television series of the romantic drama genre. It was aired on Star Plus and was produced by Balaji Telefilms.

[[Moshe Sharett]]

CATEGORIES: 1894 births, 1965 deaths, Alumni of the London School of Economics, Former Members of Knesset, Government ministers of Israel, Israeli former political leaders, Israeli journalists, Jewish Israeli politicians, Jewish Israeli writers, Mapai politicians, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Prime Ministers of Israel, Ukrainian Jews, Zionists

Moshe Sharett, Hebrew: משה שרת , born Moshe Shertok, Hebrew: משה שרתוק‬, (October 15, 1894 in Kherson (Russian Empire, nowadays Ukraine) - July 7, 1965 in Jerusalem) was an Israeli politician of Mapai Party.

Sharett moved to Ottoman Palestine in 1906. He studied at Istanbul University and the London School of Economics.

In 1920s he worked as a journalist in the United Kingdom. He returned to Mandatory Palestine in 1931, and became a member of the Assembly of Representatives.

He was one of those who signed the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel in 1948.

Sharett was chosen into the first Knesset in 1949, and stayed a Member of Knesset till his death.

He was also in the government. He was Foreign Minister from 1948 to 1956. During this time he was also Prime Minister from January 26, 1954 to November 3, 1955, succeeding fellow party member David Ben-Gurion (last one succeeded Sharett).

Moshe Sharett died in 1965 at the age of 80.

[[Cobalt (Ontario)]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Ontario

Cobalt is a town of the district of Timiskaming, in the province of Ontario, Canada.

[[Trevor Kidd]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Brandon Wheat Kings players, Calgary Flames players, Canadian ice hockey goaltenders, Carolina Hurricanes players, Florida Panthers players, Living people, Spokane Chiefs players, Toronto Maple Leafs players, American Hockey League players, International Hockey League (1945–2001) players

Trevor Rodney Kidd (born March 29, 1972) is a former NHL goaltender who last played for the Hannover Scorpions in the Deutsche Eishockey Liga. Throughout his 12-year National Hockey League career, Kidd played for the Calgary Flames, Carolina Hurricanes, Florida Panthers and Toronto Maple Leafs. A first-round draft pick, Kidd was selected 11th overall by the Flames in the 1990 NHL Entry Draft.

[[Aquilegia]]

CATEGORIES: Plants of Pakistan

Aquilegia (commonly known as granny's  bonnet or columbine) is a genus of about 60-70 species of perennial plants that are found in meadows, woodlands, and at higher altitudes throughout the Northern Hemisphere, known for the spurred petals  of their flowers.

[[José S Carrión]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Spanish scientists, Spanish writers, People from the region of Murcia

José S Carrión (Jumilla 1962) is a Spanish scientist, editor, science and cultural columnist and poet. His main research interest deals with the relationships between hominins and plants from a palaeoecological perspective. He has conducted and co-ordinated a number of research projects on the palaeoflora and palaeovegetation of the Iberian Peninsula and Balearic Islands, ecological changes linked to patterns and processes of human and cultural evolution, eco-cultural collapses, extinctions in plants, palaeoecology and biodiversity conservation and forest management, palaeoenvironments of arid regions, pollen analysis of biogenic materials and archaeological sites, pollen analyses of honeys, aerobiological monitoring (Burkard filters), forensic palynology, and spore and pollen-morphological studies.  He is full professor of Evolutionary Botany at University of Murcia, where he leads the Research Group ECCE HOMO (Evolution, Cenozoic, Quaternary, Ecology, Homo). He is currently editor in chief of Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology, and Associate Editor of Quaternary Science Reviews, Elsevier.

[[Domestic yak]]

CATEGORIES: Bovines, Domesticated animals, Mammals of Pakistan, Mammals of Asia

The domestic yak (Bos grunniens) is a long-haired domesticated bovid found throughout the Himalayan region of the Indian subcontinent, the Tibetan Plateau and as far north as Mongolia and Russia. It is descended from the wild yak (Bos mutus).

[[Hackbridge railway station]]

CATEGORIES: Railway stations in London, 1868 establishments in the United Kingdom, 1860s establishments in England, Railway stations opened in 1868

Hackbridge railway station is a train station at Hackbridge in the London Borough of Sutton in South London. The station is served by Southern and Thameslink. It is in Fare zone 4.

[[Daniel Defoe]]

CATEGORIES: 1660 births, 1731 deaths, English children's writers

Daniel Defoe (13 September 1660 – 24 April 1731) was a trader, writer, and journalist from England. His best known work is the novel Robinson Crusoe. In some languages, it is the number 2 bestseller, after the Bible.

[[White Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Society, Race, Ethnic groups in the United States

White Americans are Americans who are white. As of 2010, most Americans belong to this group. In 2010, 70% of the people living in the United States identified as being white or White Hispanics. Non-hispanic whites accounted for about 60% of the U.S. population. 

[[Carson Wentz]]

CATEGORIES: Philadelphia Eagles players, American football quarterbacks, 1992 births, Living people

Carson James Wentz (born December 30, 1992) is an American football quarterback. He plays the Indianapolis Colts in the National Football League (NFL).

He was drafted in the first round of the 2016 NFL draft. He played his first NFL game in 2016. In his first year he passed for 3,782 yards and 16 touchdowns, 14 Interceptions. His team the Eagles finished the year 7–9 and missed the playoffs. In his second year he had good season 3,296	yards and 33 touchdowns and 7 Interceptions. He was seen as an MVP candidate. The. In week 14 Wentz injured his knee against the Los Angeles Rams.

[[Romani Americans]]

CATEGORIES: Ethnic groups in the United States, Roma

Romani Americans are people in the United States whose ancestors once came from India in Ancient time's. They came to the United States via Eastern Europe at 19th century - 20th century. It is estimated that there are one million Romani people in the United States, occasionally known as American Gypsies.

[[Banana squash]]

CATEGORIES: Cucurbitaceae, Fruits

Banana squash is an edible squash, or gourd, in the Cucurbita family. developed from the butternut squash, a type of winter squash. Its name was given for its elongated shape and yellow colour. 

Like the butternut squash, it has a potato-like texture and seeds in the middle. It is classified as a fruit because it has seeds. Its mild flesh can be either sweet or savoury.

[[Carl Emil Christiansen]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2018 deaths, Danish footballers, Danish football managers

Carl Emil Christiansen (31 December 1937 – 15 January 2018) was a Danish football player.

Christiansen played 313 games and scored 112 goals for Esbjerg fB in Denmark. He was the top goalscorer of the 1962 Danish football championship, and played two games and scored one goal for the Denmark national football team.

[[Ostafrikasaurus]]

CATEGORIES: Spinosauridae, Jurassic dinosaurs

Ostafrikasaurus was a carnivorous theropod dinosaur from the Late Jurassic of southeastern Tanzania. It is known only from a fossil tooth that is 49 long. Paleontologist Eric Buffetaut claims it is the oldest evidence of a Spinosaurid dinosaur (a type of crocodile-like dinosaur that ate fish); It appeared 148 million years ago.

[[Olivia Cole]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning actors, 1942 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Mexico, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Memphis, Tennessee

Olivia Carlena Cole (November 26, 1942 – January 19, 2018) was an American actress. She was born in Memphis, Tennessee. Her career began in 1954 and ended when she retired in 2011. Cole won an Emmy Award for her role as Chicken George's wife, Matilda in the 1977 miniseries Roots. She was also known for her role as Maggie Rogers in the 1979 miniseries Backstairs at the White House.

Cole died at the age of 75 at her home in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico on January 19, 2018, after a heart attack.

[[Marcos Carvajal]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Colorado Rockies players, Florida Marlins players, Venezuelan sportspeople

Marcos José Carvajal (ˈmarkos ˈhoze karβaˈxal; 19 August 1984 – 24 January 2018) was a Venezuelan relief pitcher. He played for the Colorado Rockies and Florida Marlins of Major League Baseball.

Carvajal died of pneumonia on January 24, 2018 in Ciudad Bolívar, Venezuela at the age of 33.

[[Gonzalo Facio Segreda]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, People with Alzheimer's disease, Lawyers, Diplomats, Ambassadors to the United States, Costa Rican people

Gonzalo Justo Facio Segreda (28 March 1918 – 24 January 2018) was a Costa Rican lawyer, politician, and diplomat. He was born in San José, Costa Rica. 

Facio Segreda served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1970 to 1978, as President of the Legislative Assembly from 1953 to 1956, and later served as Ambassador to the United States from 1956 to 1958, again from 1962 to 1966 and again from 1990 to 1994.

Facio Segreda died on 24 January 2018 of pneumonia complicated by Alzheimer's disease in Escazu, Costa Rica at the age of 99.

[[Renaud Gagneux]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2018 deaths, 20th century composers, 21st century composers, Deaths from motor neurone disease, Disease-related deaths in France, French composers, People from Paris

Renaud Gagneux (15 May 1947 – 24 January 2018) was a French composer. He was born in Paris. Gagneux studied piano with Alfred Cortot and composition with Henri Dutilleux at the École Normale in Paris. In 1966 he went to Cologne to study composition with Karlheinz Stockhausen, then with André Jolivet and Olivier Messiaen at the Conservatoire de Paris. 

In 1972 he joined the Groupe de Recherches Musicales de l'ORTF. His many prizes include the Sacem Grand Prix for chamber music (1977), the Prix Georges Enesco (1983), the Prize for New Talent from the SACD (1989), the Composers' Prize of the Sacem (1990), and the SACEM Grand Prix 1993 for his works overall.

Gagneux died in Paris on 24 January 2018 of ALS-related complications at the age of 70.

[[Bristol stool scale]]

CATEGORIES: Gastroenterology, Physiology, Medical tests

The Bristol stool scale is a medical diagnosis tool used by Doctors to classify the way feces looks into 7 different categories.  It is also known by the names, Bristol stool chart and Bristol stool form scale.

It was developed at Bristol Royal Infirmary in 1997 as a clinical assessment tool, but is also used to help with patients who can't speak, so that they can show their doctor if they have a problem with their bowels (a clinical communication aid).  It's also used to help diagnose Irritable Bowel Syndrome.

[[Frank Varrichione]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from skin cancer, Cancer deaths in Massachusetts, Pittsburgh Steelers players, Los Angeles Rams players, Sportspeople from Massachusetts

Frank Joseph Varrichione (pronounced "Vair-akee-oh'-nee," January 14, 1932 – January 6, 2018) was an American athlete. He was born in Natick, Massachusetts. He played eleven seasons in the National Football League (NFL). He played for the Pittsburgh Steelers from 1955 through 1960 and with the Los Angeles Rams from 1961 to 1965.

Varrichione died on January 6, 2018 in Framingham, Massachusetts of skin cancer at the age of 85.

[[Neagu Djuvara]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Romanian historians, Essayists, Philosophers, Centenarians, Romanian journalists, Novelists, Romanian diplomats, People from Bucharest

Neagu Djuvara (ˈne̯aɡu d͡ʒjuˈvara; August 18, 1916 – January 25, 2018) was a Romanian historian, essayist, philosopher, journalist, novelist and diplomat. He was born in Bucharest. Djuvara was an active contributor to Radio Free Europe. Between 1991 and 1998, he was an Associate Professor at the University of Bucharest. During the early 1990s, he was a noted critic of Romanian political developments.

Djuvara died in Bucharest of pneumonia on January 25, 2018 at the age of 101.

[[Lyudmila Senchina]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from breast cancer, Russian singers, Russian movie actors, Soviet singers, Soviet movie actors, Ukrainian singers

Lyudmila Petrovna Senchina (Людми́ла Петро́вна Се́нчина;  13 December 1950, – 25 January 2018) was a Soviet, Ukrainian and Russian singer (soprano). 

She was also an actress, appearing in Armed and Dangerous (Вооружён и очень опасен), in which Lyudmila performed a female lead role. 

[[Patrick Mazimhaka]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2018 deaths, Civil servants, Rwandan people, African politicians

Patrick Kayumbu Mazimhaka (26 April 1948 – 25 January 2018) was a Rwandan politician. He was the former Deputy Chairperson of the African Union's African Commission. Mazimhaka was born in Rwanda. He was elected the Deputy Chairperson of the African Union Commission in July 2003 held in Maputo, Mozambique, and held the office until 6 February 2008. He was, until his election, the Senior Presidential Advisor to the President of Rwanda on the Great Lakes Region. 

Mazimhaka died in Delhi, India on 25 January 2018 at the age of 69.

[[Gustav Gerneth]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 births, 2019 deaths, German people, Supercentenarians

Gustav Gerneth (15 October 1905 – 22 October 2019) was a German World War II-veteran and at the time of his death at age 114 years, 7 days the oldest person ever in Germany and the oldest living man in the world as well as the youngest of only 8 men and only 2 European men (behind Spaniard Joan Riudavets) who have become at least 114 years old. He was born in 1905 in Stettin, which was then part of the German Empire and is now in Poland as Szczecin.

Gerneth worked in a shipping company and at a gas plant during World War II. He was a Russian prisoner-of-war until 1947 when he was released from imprisonment. He married his wife Charlotte (died in 1988) in 1930 and the couple had three sons, all of whom now deceased. 

He became the oldest living man in Europe after Spaniard Francisco Núñez-Olivera's death on 29 January 2018, and later also the first German person to become 113 and 114 years old as well as the oldest living man in the world on 19 January 2019 after the death of Japaneseman Masazo Nonaka, who was almost 12 weeks older and became the oldest living man after Núñez-Olivera's death (Nonaka died on 20 January Japanese time). Nonaka and Gerneth were, after the death of Americanman Richard Overton (also a World War II-veteran) on 27 December 2018, the last two living men born before 1907.

Gerneth lived in Saxony-Anhalt in the same brick house with steep entrance stairs for over 40 years, before his death just a week after celebrating his 114th birthday. 

[[Megalosauroidea]]

CATEGORIES: Theropods

Megalosauroidea is a group of carnivorous theropod dinosaurs. They lived from the Middle Jurassic to the Late Cretaceous period. Members of the group include Spinosaurus, Megalosaurus, and Torvosaurus.

[[Revenue division]]

CATEGORIES: Local government in India

A revenue division is an administrative division of some of the Indian states. It is a geographic area covering many mandals (taluks). These mandals consists of villages. A revenue division is headed by a Revenue Divisional Officer.

[[Alipurduar district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of West Bengal

Alipurduar district is a district in West Bengal, India. The headquarters of this district is Alipurduar city. This district was created in the year of 2014. This is the 20th district of West Bengal.

The district contains nine census towns and rural areas of 66 gram panchayats. These are under six community development blocks: Madarihat - Birpara, Alipurduar I, Alipurduar II, Falakata, Kalchini and Kumargram.

The nine census towns are Paschim Jitpur, Chechakhata, Alipurduar Railway Junction, Bholar Dabri, Sobhaganj, Falakata, Jaygaon and Uttar Latabari and Uttar Kamakhyaguri.

[[Purba Bardhaman district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of West Bengal

Purba Bardhaman district is a newly created district of West Bengal. Bardhaman district of West Bengal was divided into two new districts. These were named Purba Bardhaman district and Paschim Bardhaman district. This district has its headquarters at Bardhaman city.

[[Kolkata district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of West Bengal

Kolkata district is an administrative district of West Bengal. The city of Kolkata is headquarters of the district.

[[Aditi Sajwan]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television actors, Living people, 1991 births

Aditi Sajwan (born 12 February 1991 in Dehradun, India) is an Indian television soap opera actress. She made her acting debut in Zee TV's Meri Doli Tere Angana. After she entered Imagine TV's Rajkumaar Aaryan to play the role of Mayasheen, she played Yashoda in Jai Shri Krishna and she was seen in Meera as Meera , She was last seen on television Show Chidiya Ghar as Koyal.

[[Steve Foster]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in Australia, Australian singer-songwriters, Australian guitarists, Australian folk musicians, Australian pop musicians, Australian pop singers, Australian rock musicians, Australian rock singers, Banjo players, Musicians from South Australia

Stephen Edward Foster (30 September 1946 – 25 January 2018), better known as Steve Foster, was an Australian singer-songwriter, guitarist and banjo and harmonica player. He was born in Murray Bridge, South Australia. 

Foster's career had mostly been as a solo artist, but he has led some very successful bands as well including Inkase, Alcheringa, Head First and Limited Edition. He was the opening act on the Brian Cadd & the Bootleg Family Australian tour 1972-1973. He performed in The Mount Lofty Rangers.

In September 1972, was the release of Foster's award-winning debut solo album Coming Home In A Jar on the Bootleg Label.

In 1995 Forever Blue, a co-write with Graham Goble, first recorded by Little River Band in 1986 on the album No Reins, the last album recorded with John Farnham became a huge hit in Europe, rising into the Top 10.

Foster was an Australia Day Ambassador. He traveled each year to visit councils across South Australia to perform and explain what it means to be a proud Australian.

Foster died on 25 January 2018, in Adelaide, Australia of lung cancer at the age of 71.

[[Jeff Colyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, American physicians, Governors of Kansas, Lieutenant Governors of Kansas, US Republican Party politicians, 21st-century American politicians, Kansas Republicans

Jeffrey William Colyer (born June 3, 1960) is an American surgeon and politician. On January 31, 2018, he became the 47th Governor of Kansas. Before, he was the 49th Lieutenant Governor of Kansas serving under Governor Sam Brownback. He is a member of the Republican Party. He was a member of the Kansas Senate (2009–2011) and of the Kansas House of Representatives (2007–2009).

Colyer was a White House Fellow under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush. He worked in international affairs.

On January 24, 2018, Vice President Mike Pence broke a 49-49 tie vote to make Governor Brownback the United States Ambassador-at-Large for International Religious Freedom. Governor Brownback resigned on January 25, 2018 to serve as the ambassador, thus making Colyer the designate governor.

On August 14, 2018, Colyer lost the Republican nomination to Secretary of State Kris Kobach for Governor in the 2018 election by 345 votes.

[[Elephant polo]]

CATEGORIES: Polo, Sport in India, Sport in Nepal, Sport in Sri Lanka, Sport in Thailand

Elephant polo is a variant of polo. It is played whilst riding elephants. It is played in Nepal, Sri Lanka, India, and Thailand.

[[Ikyawann]]

CATEGORIES: Hindi-language television series, Indian television series, 2017 Indian television series debuts, 2018 television series endings, 2018 disestablishments in India

Ikyawann is a 2017 Indian television series, which is broadcast on Star Plus and stream on Hotstar. The show is  premiered on 13 November 2017.The Show is Going Off Air on 1 June 2018 and it will get replaced by Sabse Smart Kaun.

[[Maillard reaction]]

CATEGORIES: Organic reactions, Chemistry

The Maillard reaction is a chemical reaction between an amino acid and a reducing sugar that gives browned food its distinctive flavor. Seared steaks, pan-fried dumplings, cookies and other kinds of biscuits, breads, toasted marshmallows, as well as many other foods, undergo this reaction.

The reactive carbonyl group of the sugar reacts with the nucleophilic amino group of the amino acid, and forms a complex mixture of poorly characterized molecules responsible for a range of aromas and flavors. At higher temperatures, caramelization and subsequently pyrolysis become more pronounced.

[[Arang Kel]]

CATEGORIES: Hill Stations in Pakistan

Arang Kel is a village, tourist spot and a hill station located in Neelum valley, Azad Kashmir, Pakistan. It is located at a height of 8,379 feet (2,554 m).

[[Neelum Valley]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys of Azad Kashmir

Neelum Valley is located in the northern part of Azad Kashmir, Pakistan.  It includes a number of tourist spots like Arang Kel, Kel, Athmuqam and Dowarian.

[[Elizabeth Hawley]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2018 deaths, Journalists from Chicago

Elizabeth Hawley (November 9, 1923 – January 26, 2018) was an American journalist and chronicler of Himalayan expeditions. Hawley was born in Chicago, Illinois.

She was studied at the University of Michigan. She moved to Nepal after giving up her job as a researcher for Fortune magazine in New York and visiting Kathmandu on a round-the-world trip.

She found work with the Reuters news agency covering mountaineering news, including the 1963 American expedition that was the first from the United States to traverse Mount Everest.

Hawley died on 26 January 2018 at the age of 94.

[[Flag of Zimbabwe]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Zimbabwe

The flag of Zimbabwe has seven horizontal stripes of green, gold, red and black with a white triangle containing a red five-pointed star with a Zimbabwe Bird. The most recent design was adopted on April 18th, 1980. Zimbabwe won its freedom from the United Kingdom on this day. This design is adapted from the flag of the Zimbabwe African National Union, the current ruling party in Zimbabwe. 

[[Brandon Hardesty]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, Actors from Baltimore, Maryland, American Internet celebrities

Brandon Allan Hardesty (born April 13, 1987) is an American comedic performer and actor. He was born in Baltimore, Maryland.

In September 2007, upon seeing Hardesty's YouTube videos, a producer of the movie Bart Got a Room e-mailed Hardesty expressing interest in casting him for a supporting role. Hardesty was cast as a lead in a short movie "Ham Sandwich," directed by David Green. In 2013, Hardesty has been cast in roles in the movie Seven Minutes as well as The Scorpion King 4: Quest for Power, the fourth installment in the Mummy movie franchise.

[[Rimbachzell]]

Rimbachzell is a French commune. It is in the Haut-Rhin department.

Wegscheid is a commune in the Haut-Rhin department of east France.

[[Middle name]]

CATEGORIES: Names

A middle name is a name given to a person at birth or baptism.  It is different from a given name and surname. 

In most Western countries the given name comes first (before the last name or family name).  However, in many Eastern countries such as China it comes after the last name or family name, and occasionally also in Europe, e.g. in Hungarian.

[[Chips Hardy]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, English novelists, English playwrights, English television writers, Screenwriters from London, Living people

Edward John "Chips" Hardy (born 23 January 1950) is an English screenwriter, novelist, playwright, and creative director. He and Elizabeth Ann, his wife, are the parents of actor Tom Hardy, with whom Hardy worked on BBC One's drama series Taboo, as the co-creator, a writer and a consulting producer.

[[Nick Palatas]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, American movie actors, American television actors, Living people, Actors from Maryland, People from Bethesda, Maryland, American voice actors

Nicholas Edward "Nick" Palatas (born January 22, 1988) is an American actor. He has appeared in two short movies, titled The Erogenous Zone and Love and has been in several ads. In 2009, he played Norville "Shaggy" Rogers in the movie, Scooby-Doo! The Mystery Begins and reprised the role in Scooby-Doo! Curse of the Lake Monster which released in October 2010.

[[Hiromu Nonaka]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Japanese politicians

Hiromu Nonaka was a Japanese LDP politician. He served as a local politician from 1951 to 1978 and in the House of Representatives from 1983 to 2003. He served as Minister of Home Affairs and Head of the National Public Safety Commission from 1994 to 1995, as Chief Cabinet Secretary from 1998 to 1999, and as Head of the Okinawa Development Agency in 1999.

[[Jacques Languirand]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Canadian radio personalities, Canadian novelists, Canadian movie actors, Actors from Montreal, Writers from Montreal

Jacques Languirand (May 1, 1931 – January 26, 2018) was a Canadian radio host, writer, and actor. He was born in Montreal, Quebec.

He hosted the same radio show, Par 4 chemins on Radio-Canada, for 42 years. He was awarded the C.M. (Member of the Order of Canada) on December 21, 1987, and the O.C. (Officer of the Order of Canada) on May 8, 2003.

In 2012, he became a known actor in Martin Villeneuve's Mars et Avril, a science fiction movie based on the graphic novels of the same name.

Languirand in Montreal of Alzheimer's disease on January 26, 2018 at the age of 86.

[[Star India]]

CATEGORIES: Media in Asia, Companies of India

Star India (also known as  Star India Private Limited) is the largest media company of India. This media operator has 58 channels in eight languages. On 14 December 2017, The Walt Disney Company announced that it would acquire 21st Century Fox's Entertainment Division for $52.4 billion. Since Star India is owned by Fox it will automatically be one of the assets acquired by Disney. STAR India announced it has successfully completed the integration of the broadcast business of MAA TV in a deal estimated to be between Rs 2,000 to 2,500 crore. The have STAR sports group has planned to build a national sports network in India. The plan includes broadcasting in Indian languages. Star CJ Alive and depends mainly on infomercials. On 14 November 2012 Star CJ Alive appointed Kenny Shin as CEO for India.

[[Herbolzheim]]

Herbolzheim is a town in Baden-Württemberg, Germany.

It is near the river Elz, 26 km north of Freiburg.

[[Caihong]]

CATEGORIES: Fossil taxa described in 2018

Caihong (cǎihóng) is an extinct dinobird from Late Jurassic China. Caihong was discovered in 2014. The animal may predate the famous Aurornis xui, the earliest bird, by about 1 million years.

The type species, Caihong juji, was named in 2018.

[[Kel]]

CATEGORIES: Hill Stations in Pakistan

Kel (کیل) is a village in Neelum Valley, Azad Kashmir, Pakistan. It is located at a height of 6879. It is near the Line of Control.

[[Nguyễn Thị Kim Ngân]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnamese politicians

Nguyễn Thị Kim Ngân (born 12 April 1954 in Bến Tre Province) is a Vietnamese politician currently serving as Chairwoman of the National Assembly of Vietnam and the first woman to take the position. Previously, she served as Vice President of the National Assembly, Minister of Labor and President of Hải Dương Province. She replaced Nguyễn Sinh Hùng as Chairwoman of the National Assembly on 31 March 2016.

[[Jhelam Valley]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys of Azad Kashmir

Jhelam Valley (وادی جہلم) is a valley in Azad Kashmir, Pakistan. It is a 50 kilometers (31 miles) long valley located along with Jhelam River.

[[Samahni Valley]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys of Azad Kashmir

Samahni valley is a valley located on the Line of Control that separates Azad Kashmir from Indian Occupied Kashmir. It covers an area of 1270 km2 and is the largest valley in Kashmir by area covered.

[[Olivia Longott]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Actors from Brooklyn, Singers from New York City

Olivia Theresa Longott (born 15 February 1981, in Brooklyn, New York, USA) is an American actress and  singer. She was also on the Love & Hip Hop: New York series.

[[Northwestern Memorial Hospital]]

CATEGORIES: Hospitals in the United States, Buildings and structures in Chicago, Illinois

Northwestern Memorial Hospital (NMH) is a medical center hospital in the Magnificent Mile in Chicago, Illinois. It is the teaching hospital for Northwestern University's Feinberg School of Medicine. 

Along with its Prentice Women’s Hospital and Stone Institute of Psychiatry, the hospital has a total of 894 patient beds. The hospital has over 1,600 physicians on the medical staff at Northwestern Memorial who also carry faculty appointments with Feinberg. It is the third tallest hospital in the United States and the fifth tallest hospital in the world.

[[Lingwa de planeta]]

CATEGORIES: Constructed languages

Lingwa de planeta (also Lidepla or LdP) is a constructed international auxiliary language. It uses words from the ten most widely spoken languages in the world: Arabic, Chinese, English, Spanish, German, Hindi, Persian, Portuguese, Russian and French.

[[Folkspraak]]

CATEGORIES: Constructed languages

Folkspraak (also Folksprák and Folksprak; from folk 'people' and spraak 'language', which means "the language of the people") is an unfinished zonal constructed language. It uses words from Germanic languages to make it easy for anyone who speaks those languages to understand it. It works a lot like a lingua franca for people who speak Germanic languages.

[[Qigong]]

CATEGORIES: Meditation, Chinese culture

Qigong (氣功), also known as qi gong, chi kung, or chi gung, is a holistic system of coordinated body posture and movement, breathing, and meditation used for health, spirituality, and martial arts training. With roots in Chinese medicine, philosophy, and martial arts, qigong is traditionally viewed as a practice to cultivate and balance qi (chi), translated as "life energy".

[[Romagny, Haut-Rhin]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Romagny is a commune in the Haut-Rhin department in Alsace in east France.

[[Arnold Roth]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, American cartoonists, American illustrators, People from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Arnold Roth (born February 25, 1929) is an American freelance cartoonist and illustrator. He worked in advertisements, album covers, books, magazines, and newspapers. 

Novelist John Updike wrote, "All cartoonists are geniuses, but Arnold Roth is especially so".

[[Byron Langley]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Politicians from North Dakota, US Democratic Party politicians

Byron J. Langley (November 11, 1926 – January 13, 2018) was an American politician. He was born Warwick, North Dakota.

Langley was a member of the North Dakota House of Representatives serving as a Democrat. He represented the 12th district from 1973 to 1980. He also served in the North Dakota Senate from 1985 to 1996.  On April 21, 1993 the Fifty-third Legislative Assembly unanimously elected Langley to the office of the President Pro Tempore; which he held through 1994. 

Langley died on January 13, 2018 in Carrington, North Dakota of complications from Alzheimer's disease at the age of 91.

[[Javiera Muñoz]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, 2018 deaths, Swedish singers, Pop singers, Latin singers

Javiera Margarita Odija Ubal Muñoz (28 May 1977 – 18 January 2018) was a Swedish singer. She was of Chilean-Spanish descent. She participated in Melodifestivalen twice, in 2000 with Varje timma, var minut, and in 2002 with No hay nada más. She was born in Motala, Sweden.

In 2003, she received a musical grant for promoting Latino Music in Sweden.

Muñoz died on 18 January 2018 in Gothenburg, Sweden at the age of 40.

[[Dharmasena Pathiraja]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from respiratory tract infection, Sri Lankan movie directors, Screenwriters, Educators

Dharmasena Pathiraja (28 March 1943 – 28 January 2018) was a Sri Lankan movie director, screenwriter and educator. He was born in Kandy, Sri Lanka. He was known for his movies Eya Dan Loku Lamayek (1975) and Bambaru Avith (1978).

Pathiraja started his academic career at the University of Kelaniya as an assistant lecturer. Later he worked as a lecturer in several Sri Lankan universities, including, University of Jaffna, University of Ruhuna and University of Colombo.

Pathiraja died in Kandy on 28 January 2018 from a respiratory tract infection at the age of 74.

[[Royal Galipeau]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from multiple myeloma, Cancer deaths in Ontario, Canadian businesspeople, Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Ontario

Royal Galipeau (January 5, 1947 – January 27, 2018) was a Canadian politician and businessman. He served as a Member of Parliament for the Ottawa—Orléans federal constituency. He was first elected as a Conservative Party candidate in the 2006 election, and was reelected in 2008 and 2011. He lost in the 2015 t0 retired Canadian Forces Lieutenant-General Andrew Leslie.

In February 2014, he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma, but insisted he would run for office again in the 2015 election. He died form the disease on January 27, 2018 in Ottawa, Ontario at the age of 70.

[[Mohammed Al-Mfarah]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from laryngeal cancer, Saudi Arabian people, Civil servants, Movie actors, Television actors, Stage actors, Movie directors, Movie producers, Playwrights

Mohammed Al-Mfarah, also known as Abu Samah (محمد المفرح) (May 20, 1945 – January 23, 2018), was a Saudi Arabian actor, playwright, director and producer. He was born in Al-Zilfi, Saudi Arabia. He worked at the ministry of health and submitted his resignation in 1975.

Al-Mfarah was known for his movie roles in Al-Saknat Fe Klobna (The inhabitants in our hearts), Secretary in the House, Ahtarq Al-Samah (Candle burning), and Abo Samah Fe Fanaq Al-Samrine (Abu Samah in Al-Samaren Hotel). He also appeared in the plays Al-Mohsan (Enhanced) and Bokor Wa kolampor (Incense and Kualalumpur).

Al-Mfarah died in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on January 23, 2018 of laryngeal cancer at the age of 72.

[[Goosebumps (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 American television series debuts, Canadian children's television series, American horror television series, American children's television series, 1998 television series endings, 1995 establishments in Canada, 1998 disestablishments in the United States, 1990s disestablishments in Canada, English-language television programs

Goosebumps is a Canadian-American horror anthology television series based on R. L. Stine's best-selling Goosebumps book series. It ran from October 27, 1995 through November 16, 1998. Goosebumps originally began airing on YTV (in English) and Canal Famille (in French) in Canada and on Fox Kids in the United States.

From October 7, 2007 to September 7, 2009, Cartoon Network aired the episodes. From September 6, 2011 until September 1, 2014, The Hub broadcast the series.

The opening sequence starts with a man dressed in black carrying his briefcase up a hill. The name engraved on the briefcase reveals the mysterious man to be Goosebumps' author, R. L. Stine. Hour-long specials The Haunted Mask I & II, A Night In Terror Tower, The Werewolf of Fever Swamp, Welcome to Dead House and Night of the Living Dummy III don't use the opening sequence at all but instead have R.L. Stine introducing those episodes and also appearing at the end.

[[Lurie Children's Hospital]]

CATEGORIES: Hospitals in the United States, Buildings and structures in Chicago, Illinois

Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago (formerly Children's Memorial Hospital) located in Magnificent Mile in Streeterville, Chicago, Illinois is a pediatric specialty hospital. The hospital has more than 1,200 physicians on its medical staff and 4,000 employees. 

Based on volume, it is ranked #1 regionally in all pediatric specialties and is accredited by the Joint Commission (formerly known as the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations). Physicians and staff provided highly specialized care for more than 148,000 children in 2011, from every U.S. state and 35 countries.

[[Cyberchase]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning programs, American children's television series, Canadian children's television series, 2002 television series debuts

Cyberchase was an American/Canadian animated educational children's television series on PBS Kids. The series about three children from Earth: Jackie, Matt, and Inez. They were brought into Cyberspace, a digital universe, in order to protect the world from the villain Hacker (voiced by Christopher Lloyd). These kids are able to prevent Hacker from destroying Cyberspace by means of problem-solving skills with basic math. In Cyberspace, they meet Digit (voiced by Gilbert Gottfried), a cybird that helps them on their missions.

It was first shown on WNET as a "sneak peek" on March 24, 2000, before making its official debut on January 21, 2002. In 2010, after the season eight finale, PBS put the series on hiatus, but it returned in 2013 for a ninth season, followed by a tenth season in 2015. The eleventh season premiered on October 23, 2017. There was a twelfth season that premiered on April 19, 2019.

[[Erica Mena]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people

Erica Mena (Born November 8, 1987) is an actress, writer and Hip hop singer.Mena is known for her appearances in the show Love & Hip Hop: New York

.She has wrote the books Chronicles of a Confirmed Bachelorette and Underneath It All.

[[Rashidah Ali]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people

Rashidah Ali (better known as Rah Ali)  (Born January 27, 1984). She is known for her appearances on Love & HipHop: New York. She has had a long friendship with fellow Love & HipHop: New York star: Remy Ma for some time. Though not friends anymore. She is described as wild & not one to back down from a fight. As wife and now mother, the business woman Rah Ali has made a success trail for herself.

[[Test cricket]]

CATEGORIES: Cricket

Test cricket is the longest and oldest type of international cricket. The first officially recognized Test match took place on 15–19 March 1877 and was played between England and Australia at the Melbourne Cricket Ground, where Australia won by 45 runs. 

The early test matches were played by England against other sides in the British Empire. First test matches took place in these years:

Test matches eventually spread to other countries around the world. Later came One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 internationals (T20s). 

Test matches are a series of 5-day matches. Each team's two innings' scores are added to find the total runs. The team with more runs wins the match if the other team has completed both of their innings, with there being a tie if they have an equal number of runs; otherwise it is a draw. 

[[Truist Park]]

CATEGORIES: Major League Baseball venues, Atlanta Braves, Sports buildings in Atlanta, Georgia

Truist Park, originally known as SunTrust Park, is a baseball stadium in a section of Cobb County, Georgia that has an Atlanta mailing address. It is the home of the Atlanta Braves of Major League Baseball (MLB).

During the stadium's planning process, it was named SunTrust Park when the Braves reached a naming agreement with the Atlanta-based SunTrust banking company. In February 2019, SunTrust merged with another banking company, BB&T, and the new company renamed itself Truist. However, the ballpark kept the SunTrust name through the 2019 season. The new name of Truist Park became official on January 14, 2020. 

[[Nieuw-Vennep]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Holland, Haarlemmermeer

Nieuw-Vennep is a town in the Netherlands. It is right below Amsterdam and Amsterdam Schiphol Airport. Around 30,000 people live in the town.

[[Dennis Peron]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2018 deaths, LGBT people from New York, Gay men, American political activists, American LGBT rights activists, Businesspeople from New York City, Writers from New York City, Writers from San Francisco, Businesspeople from San Francisco

Dennis Peron (April 6, 1946 – January 27, 2018) was an American activist and businessman. He was born in New York City. He was an important figure for the legality of cannabis throughout the 1990s. He influenced many in California and led the political debate on marijuana in the United States.

Peron was openly gay and his partner died of AIDS in 1990. Peron sold cannabis and advocated for medical cannabis. In 1991, he cofounded the Cannabis Buyers Club, the first public cannabis dispensary.

In 1996, the Grassroots Party of Minnesota fielded Peron, as their first Presidential nominee, in the U.S. presidential election. Peron won 5,400 votes. In 1998, Peron ran in the Republican primary for Governor of California, but lost to Attorney General Dan Lungren.

Peron died of lung cancer in San Francisco, California on January 27, 2018 at the age of 71.

[[Kabul ambulance bombing]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 in Asia, 2010s explosions in Asia, 2010s in Afghanistan, 21st century in Kabul, Attacks on buildings and structures in 2018, Building bombings in Asia, Car and truck bombings in Asia, Crime in Afghanistan, Explosions in 2018, Explosions in Afghanistan, Islamic terrorist incidents in Asia, Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2010s, January 2018 events, Mass murder in 2018, Massacres in Asia, Suicide bombings in Asia, Suicide bombings in the 2010s, Suicide car and truck bombings, Taliban, Terrorist incidents in 2018, Terrorist incidents in Asia in the 2010s

The 2018 Kabul ambulance bombing happened on 27 January 2018 near Sidarat Square in Kabul, Afghanistan. At least 103 people have been killed and 235 others wounded in the suicide attack. The Taliban were behind the attack.

A bomb was hidden in an ambulance and exploded at a second police checkpoint, according to officials. Its blast also destroyed vehicles, shops, and buildings nearby.

At least 103 people were killed and 235 others were injured.

[[Zhong Zhong and Hua Hua]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 births, Individual animals, Monkeys, Living people

Zhong Zhong (中中 pinyin:Zhōng Zhōng, born 27 November 2017) and Hua Hua (华华 pinyin:Huá Huá, born 5 December 2017) are identical macaques that were made through somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT), the same cloning technique that made Dolly the sheep in 1996.

Zhong Zhong and Hua Hua are the first cloned primates made this way. When other scientists tried to clone monkeys before this, they used donated embryonic stem cells, but Zhong Zhong and Hua Hua came from donated nuclei from fetal cells, which is harder to do. The two baby monkeys were both born at the Institute of Neuroscience of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Shanghai.

[[Larry Nassar]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American physicians, American sex offenders, American people convicted of assault, People from Michigan

Lawrence Gerard Nassar (born August 16, 1963) is a Syrian American convicted serial child molester. He was the USA Gymnastics national team doctor and an osteopathic physician at Michigan State University.

Nassar's acts of assault sparked the USA Gymnastics sex abuse scandal, in which he was accused of molesting at least 150 underage girls, including a number of well-known Olympic gymnasts. The allegations against him date as far back as 1992. He has admitted to at least ten of the accusations. Some writers described him as a hebephilic doctor.

In July 2017, Nassar was sentenced to 60 years in federal prison after pleading guilty to child pornography charges. On January 24, 2018, Nassar was sentenced to 40 to 175 years in a state prison in Michigan after pleading guilty to the sexual assault of minors. 

[[Maryo J. de los Reyes]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2018 deaths, Movie directors, Television directors, Filipino people, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Mario Margarito "Maryo" Jorolan de los Reyes (December 12, 1952 – January 27, 2018) was a Filipino movie and television director. He was born in Santa Cruz, Manila. His 2003 movie Magnifico was entered into the 54th Berlin International Film Festival.

Reyes suffered a heart attack and died on 27 January 2018 in Dipolog, Zamboanga del Norte, Philippines, at the age of 65.

[[Stephen Frears]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, English movie directors, English television directors

Stephen Arthur Frears (born 20 June 1941) is an English movie and television director. He was born in Leicester, England.

Frears has directed numerous movies since the 1980s including My Beautiful Laundrette, Dangerous Liaisons, High Fidelity, The Queen, Philomena, and Florence Foster Jenkins. He has been nominated for two Academy Awards for Best Director: for The Grifters and The Queen. In 2008 The Daily Telegraph named him among the 100 most influential people in British culture.

The flag of Mozambique was adopted on May 1, 1983.

The flag of Kenya (Swahili: Bendera ya Kenya) was adopted on 12 December 1963.

[[Roger Christian]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Movie directors from London, Academy Award winners

Roger Christian (born 25 February 1944) is an English set decorator, production designer and feature movie director. Christian was born in London, England.

He won an Academy Award for his work on the original Star Wars and was Oscar-nominated for his work on Alien. Christian directed the second unit on both Return of the Jedi and Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace as well as feature movies including The Sender and Nostradamus. He also directed the 2000 movie Battlefield Earth which is regarded as one of the worst movies ever made.

In 2006, he directed an action/adventure/mystery movie, Prisoners of the Sun, starring John Rhys-Davies, David Charvet, Carmen Chaplin, and Gulshan Grover.

[[Flag of Portugal]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Portugal

The flag of Portugal (Bandeira de Portugal) is the national flag of the Portuguese Republic. It has a vertical bicolour of green and red, with the lesser coat of arms of Portugal centred over the colour boundary.

[[Michael Federmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Israeli businesspeople

Michael Ilan Yoel "Mikey" Federmann (born 9 September 1943, Haifa) is an Israeli businessman and entrepreneur, owner of the Israeli conglomerate Federmann Enterprises.

He is Chairman of the Board at Dan Hotels Ltd. He has served as CEO or Director at several companies and organizations, including Eurofund L.P, Elbit Systems Ltd, the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Governors 29 January 2018.

[[Parathyroid glands]]

CATEGORIES: Glands, Endocrine system

Parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands in the neck of humans and all tetrapods ,embedded in the posterior surface of the Thyroid glands .

CATEGORIES: Software

[[Vicente Calderón Stadium]]

CATEGORIES: Football stadiums in Spain

The Vicente Calderón Stadium (Spanish: Estadio Vicente Calderón) was the home stadium of Atlético Madrid from 1966 to 2017. It had a capacity of 54,907 and is located on the banks of the Manzanares River, in the Arganzuela district of Madrid, Spain. The stadium was originally called the Estadio Manzanares from 1966 to 1971, but this was later changed to the Vicente Calderón Stadium in 1972, in honor of their club President Vicente Calderón. The stadium will be demolished in 2018.

[[Ford Fairlane (Americas)]]

CATEGORIES: Ford automobiles, 1950s automobiles, 1960s automobiles, 1970s automobiles

The Ford Fairlane was a car from Ford Motor Company. The car was made between 1955 and 1970. The name comes off Henry Ford's estate Fair Lane, next to Dearborn, Michigan.

The name meant a number of different cars. The Fairlane was originally a full-sized car; it became a mid-sized car from the 1962 model year on.

In 1957, with the Fairlane, Ford outsold Chevrolet for the first time since 1935. For 1958, it was given quad headlights.

[[Kaduna State]]

CATEGORIES: States of Nigeria

Kaduna State is one of the major states in the central northern region of Nigeria. Its capital is the city of Kaduna. It is one of the 36 states located in the northern area of Nigeria, and is the ninth largest state in the country. Hausa is Kaduna State's most widely spoken language, while English is its official language. Other local languages are also spoken, such as Yoruba, Igbo, Fula and English Creole among others. Some of these local languages are also used in written form. The total population of the state was projected to be 8,252,400 as of March 21, 2016.

[[Ford Country Squire]]

CATEGORIES: Ford automobiles, 1950s automobiles, 1960s automobiles, 1970s automobiles, 1980s automobiles, 1990s automobiles

The Ford Country Squire was a station wagon from Ford Motor Company. It was first made in 1950. The car got started as a "woodie", a car with wood material making up part of the car. But by 1952, the Country Squire was no longer a true woodie. However, all Country Squires were made with steel and wood.

From the 1960s to the early 1980s, many variations of the Squire name were used on wood-grained cars, like the LTD II, Falcon, Escort and the mid-sized LTD.

During the mid-1980s, sales of full-size station wagons began to go down. This was after the Chrysler and Ford Aerostar minivans began being made. 

At Ford, the role for the 8-passenger station wagon was given to Mercury Sable and Ford Taurus in 1992.

[[Santa Clara Valley]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys of California, San Francisco Bay Area, San Benito County, California, Santa Clara County, California

Santa Clara Valley is a valley in California, United States formed by the Santa Cruz Mountains to the west and the Diablo Mountain Range to the east. It has many cities including San Jose and Santa Clara.

[[Interslavic language]]

CATEGORIES: Slavic languages, Constructed languages

Interslavic is a constructed language meant to be used by Slavic people. It is like a modern version of the Old Church Slavonic language of the 9th century. It is based on words and other things that exist in all Slavic languages. The idea is that Slavs from any country can understand it without learning it first. 

[[Judith Yovel Recanati]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, Israeli businesspeople

Judith Yovel Recanati (born 1951, Tel Aviv)  is an Israeli businesswoman and entrepreneur. She is the founder and chair of the Gandyr Foundation. She is also the co-founder and chairperson of NATAL, a trauma center for victims of terrorism and war. She also is on the Board of Trustees of Tel Aviv University.

[[Chico fruit]]

CATEGORIES: Tropical fruit

Sapodilla (ˌ), which is also called chico (ˈ) in the Philippines, is a large evergreen tree that is native to the tropical areas of North and South America, and Southeast Asia. It produces a fruit that can be eaten. Chicle, which is produced from the bark, is a substance used in chewing gum.  and chico is rich in iron, calcium, potassium, and phosphorus.

[[COLORS TV]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television, Television channels

Colors TV is a Hindi-language general entertainment television channel, based in India. The channel was aired on 21 July 2008, typically broadcasting drama, horror, comedy and movies. Longest Running Shows broadcast by the channel are Balika Vadhu, Sasural Simar Ka and Uttaran. It is the official brodcaster of Bigg Boss, Jhalak Dikhla Jaa, Celebrity Cricket League & Miss India.

[[Raciology]]

CATEGORIES: Race, Anthropology, Sociology

Raciology (also known as racialism, racial science, or racial biology) is the study of human race, The term is not used very much in anthropology any more, because to some anthropologists it is considered outdated and racist.

[[Dick King (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2018 deaths, American educators, Politicians from Washington, US Democratic Party politicians

Richard Anderson King (August 30, 1934 – January 15, 2018) was an American politician and educator. He was a member of the Democratic Party. King was born in Ritzville, Washington. He was also an educator teaching at Everett Community College. He retired in 1991.

King died on January 15, 2018 in Port Angeles, Washington at the age of 83.

[[Central Java]]

Central Java is a province in Indonesia. It is on the island of Java.

[[Borys Yukhymovych Steklyar]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2018 deaths, Military people, Spies, Ukrainian people

Borys Yukhymovych Steklyar (Бори́с Юхи́мович Стекляр, Борис Ефимович Стекляр (29 January 1923 – 18 January 2018) was a Ukrainian colonel of Committee for State Security of USSR. He was one of the main specialists in combating Ukrainian Insurgent Army in Rivne region. He was accused in the murder of two or more people in March 1952, including artist and member of Volyn regional OUN propaganda Referenty Nil Khasevych and two of his colleagues.

[[John Morris (composer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from respiratory tract infection, American composers, American pianists, American conductors, Writers from New Jersey

John Leonard Morris (October 18, 1926 – January 25, 2018) was an American movie, television and broadway composer, dance arranger, conductor, and trained concert pianist. He was known for composing the movie scores for Blazing Saddles, Young Frankenstein, The Elephant Man (for which he was nominated for a Grammy for its score) and Dirty Dancing.

Morris died at his home in Red Hook, New York on January 25, 2018 of a respiratory tract infection at the age of 91.

[[John Wall (inventor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2018 deaths, British  engineers, English inventors, English astronomers, People from Kent

John Wall (26 June 1932 – 27 January 2018) was an English design engineer, amateur astronomer, and amateur telescope maker. He was a  member of the British Astronomical Association until his death in 2018. He was known for designing dialyte based refracting telescopes, coming up with the Zerochromat.

Wall died on 27 January 2018 in Coventry, Warwickshire at the age of 85.

[[Antônio Agostinho Marochi]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Brazilian people, Roman Catholics

Antônio Agostinho Marochi (28 August 1925 – 28 January 2018) was a Roman Catholic bishop. He was born in Londrina, Brazil.

Marochi was ordained to the priesthood in 1953. He served as auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Londrina, Brazil from 1973 to 1976. He then served as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Presidente Prudente, Brazil from 1976 to 2002.

Marochi died of respiratory failure in Londrina on 28 January 2018 at the age of 92.

[[Ion Ciubuc]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2018 deaths, Prime Ministers of Moldova

Ion Ciubuc (May 29, 1943 – January 29, 2018) was a Moldovan politician. He was the Prime Minister of Moldova from January 1997 to February 1999. He was born in Hădărăuţi, Romania.

Ciubuc died on January 29, 2018 in Chișinău, Moldova at the age of 74.

[[Coco Schumann]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2018 deaths, Autobiographers, Guitarists, Holocaust survivors, Jazz musicians, Jewish German musicians, Jewish German writers, Musicians from Berlin, Writers from Berlin

Heinz Jakob "Coco" Schumann (14 May 1924 – 28 January 2018) was a German jazz musician of Jewish descent  and Holocaust survivor. He was born in Berlin. He became a member of the Ghetto Swingers while in Auschwitz. In the aftermath of the Holocaust, Schumann performed as a jazz guitarist, performing with Marlene Dietrich, Ella Fitzgerald, and Helmut Zacharias.

His autobiography The Ghetto Swinger: A Berlin Jazz-Legend Remembers was published in 1997.

Schumann died in Berlin on 28 January 2018 at the age of 93.

[[National Harbor, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Maryland

National Harbor is a census-designated place along the Potomac River in Oxon Hill, Prince George's County, Maryland just south of Washington, D.C.. It began as a 300 multi-use waterfront development. In the 2010 census, its population was 3,788. The conservative event CPAC is located in National Harbor.

[[List of Google Easter eggs]]

CATEGORIES: Google

Since the version 2.3 (Gingerbread) of Google's Android operating system an easter egg containing an animation has been hidden. The easter egg can be accessed through the "Settings" application, in the "About phone" section, by repeatedly tapping the "Android version" section. The animation is different in every version of the OS.

[[Eschweiler Hauptbahnhof]]

CATEGORIES: 1841 establishments in Europe, 1840s establishments in Germany, Buildings and structures in North Rhine-Westphalia, Eschweiler, Railway stations in Germany

Eschweiler Hauptbahnhof is the main and also biggest railway station of the German town of Eschweiler in North Rhine-Westphalia.

It was opened in September 1841, and is on the line Aachen-Cologne.

Eschweiler Central railway station lies about 700 meters from inner town.

[[Flanders]]

CATEGORIES: Flanders, Divided regions

Flanders (Vlaanderen ˈvlaːndərə(n), Flandre flɑ̃dʁ, Flandern, flɑndɛɹn) is the Dutch-speaking northern portion of Belgium, although there are several overlapping definitions, including ones related to culture, language, politics and history.

[[HaMahaneh HaTziyoni]]

[[Eduard Bloch]]

CATEGORIES: Austrian physicians

Eduard Bloch was an Austrian doctor practicing in Linz (Austria) and until 1907 the physician of Adolf Hitler's family.

Bloch was born in Frauenberg (today Hluboká nad Vltavou, Czech Republic), studied medicine in Prague and then served as a medical officer in the Austrian army. In 1899 he was stationed in Linz and opened a private doctor’s practice after his discharge in 1901 in the baroque house at 12 Landstrasse, where he also lived with his family: his wife, Emilie (née Kafka) and their daughter Trude, born in 1903. According to Linz’s future mayor Ernst Koref, Bloch was held in high regard, particularly among the lower and indigent social classes. It was generally known that at any time at night he was willing to call on patients. He used to go on visits in his hansom, wearing a conspicuous broad-brimmed hat. Like most Jews in Linz at the time, the Bloch family were assimilated.

[[Thyroid hormones]]

CATEGORIES: Hormones

Thyroid hormones are produced by thyroid glands. T3 and T4 are thyroid hormones that are made up of iodine and tyrosine. Less intake of iodine results in less production of T3 and T4 which may lead to a medical condition called hypothyroidism. Greater production of thyroid hormones leads to hyperthyroidism.

[[Mark Salling]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, 2018 deaths, Actors from Dallas, Texas, Actors who committed suicide, American bass guitarists, American composers, American movie actors, American sex offenders, American singer-songwriters, American television actors, Criminals from Texas, Criminals who committed suicide, Musicians from Dallas, Texas, People convicted of child pornography offenses, Singers from Dallas, Texas, Suicide in 2018, Suicides by asphyxiation, Suicides by hanging in the United States, Writers from Texas

Mark Wayne Salling (August 17, 1982 – January 30, 2018) was an American actor, singer-songwriter, composer, musician and convicted sex offender. He was known for his role as Noah "Puck" Puckerman on the television series Glee. He was born in Dallas, Texas.

In December 2015, Salling was arrested for having several thousand photos and videos showing child pornography. In October 2017, Salling pleaded guilty and faced four to seven years in prison. His sentencing hearing was set in March 2018.

Salling committed suicide by hanging at his home in Los Angeles, California on January 30, 2018 at the age of 35.

[[Clyde Scott]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2018 deaths, American track and field athletes, Detroit Lions players, Philadelphia Eagles players, American Olympic silver medalists, Sportspeople from Louisiana

Clyde Luther Scott (August 29, 1924 – January 30, 2018) was an American athlete. He competed professionally in the National Football League and earned an Olympic medal in the 110 meter hurdles. He was born in Dixie, Louisiana. He played for the Philadelphia Eagles from 1949 through 1952 and for the Detroit Lions in 1952.

Scott died on January 30, 2018, at age 93.

[[Kevin Towers]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from thyroid cancer, Cancer deaths in San Diego County, Businesspeople from Oregon, Sportspeople from Oregon, People from Medford, Oregon

Kevin S. Towers (November 11, 1961 – January 30, 2018) was an American executive. He worked with Major League Baseball. He served as the  General Manager of the San Diego Padres from 1995 to 2009 and for the Arizona Diamondbacks from 2010 to 2014. He was born in Medford, Oregon.

Towers died on January 30, 2018 in San Diego, California of thyroid cancer at the age of 56.

[[Zindagi Ki Mehek]]

CATEGORIES: Hindi-language television series, 2016 Indian television series debuts

[[Frank Santora]]

Frank Santora is the lead pastor of Faith Church in New Milford , Connecticut.  One of the few mega churches in New England.  With almost five thousand members.  

He is a host on the TBN world wide television network.  

He is the author of three books - 

- Turn It Around

- Identity Crisis

- After You Die

He is a co-author of over twenty songs.  

He is the architect of Faith Village.  A neighborhood built to house the families who were victims of Hurricane Sandy.

[[Mediacom]]

CATEGORIES: Television, Telephone companies, Internet service providers, American technology companies

Mediacom Communications is an American cable television, internet and telephone company. It was founded in July 1995.

The company serves Columbia, Jefferson City and Springfield, Missouri, the Quad Cities of southeast Iowa and western Illinois, Cedar Rapids, Iowa City and Waterloo in Iowa. It also serves certain areas of Minnesota, Alabama and outlying areas of the Florida Gulf Coast. It serves a total of twenty-two states.

Mediacom was a publicly traded firm. It later went private. It is nowwhen owned by Commisso.

[[Yacht charter management]]

CATEGORIES: Business

Yacht charter management is a business agreement between the charter organization and yacht proprietor where yacht proprietor approves charter organization for offering on-board accommodation and all other related marine operations.

[[École nationale supérieure de mécanique et des microtechniques]]

CATEGORIES: Technical colleges and universities in France, 1902 establishments in France, Besançon

École nationale supérieure de mécanique et des microtechniques is a renowned graduate engineering school in France. It is in a campus of the University of Franche-Comté.

Its different curricula lead to the following French & European degrees :

Academic activities and industrial applied research are performed mainly in French and English languages. Students from a dozen of nationalities participate to the different curricula at ENSMM.

The school is specialized in watchmaking and microtechnology.

[[Newark, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Cities in the San Francisco Bay Area, Settlements in Alameda County, California, 1955 establishments in California

Newark is a city in Alameda County, California, United States. It was created as a city in September 1955. Newark is an enclave, surrounded by the city of Fremont, California. The three cities of Newark, Fremont, and Union City make up the "Tri-City" area. Its estimated population was 44,205 in 2015.

[[Nihonium]]

CATEGORIES: Chemical elements, Metals

Nihonium (ニホニウム) is a chemical element. It is also named eka-thallium. It has the symbol Nh. It has the atomic number 113. It is a transuranium element.The name nihonium from Japan"s name nihonニホン. 

Nihonium does not exist in nature, but is artificial. It is made from the alpha decay of moscovium.

There are no known uses for nihonium. What nihonium looks like is not known because not enough has been made to see it with human eyesight. Based on trends in the Periodic Table it could be soft, silver color, very reactive metal like sodium.

[[Parathyroid hormone]]

CATEGORIES: Hormones

Parathyroid hormone is a hormone which is secreted by the parathyroid glands. These hormones release calcium into the blood to raise calcium levels, making bones stronger. Too little of these hormones can result in hypoparathyroidism and too much of it can lead to hyperparathyroidism.

[[MUFG Bank]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 establishments in Japan, Banks

MUFG Bank, Ltd. is a Japanese bank holding company headquartered in Chiyoda, Tokyo, Japan.

MUFG holds assets of around US$2.459 trillion as of 2016, making it the world's fifth largest bank by total assets and is one of the main companies of the Mitsubishi Group. It is Japan's largest financial group and the world's second largest bank holding company holding around US$1.8 trillion (JPY 148 trillion) in deposits as of March 2011. MUFG is the second largest public company in Japan when measured by market capitalization. The letters MUFG come from Mitsubishi and United Financial of Japan, the name of an acquired company.

[[Moin Nawaz Warraich]]
