Khola Amjad (خولہ امجد; born 12 December 1952) is a Pakistani politician and the member of the Provincial Assembly of the Punjab since May 2013.

[[Montreat, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in North Carolina

Montreat is a town in Buncombe County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 723 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Asheville city area. The town is best known for Montreat Conference Center, Montreat College, and for having been the home of the evangelist Billy Graham and his wife Ruth Bell Graham.

[[Andrew Yang]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, American political writers, American political commentators, Businesspeople from New York City, Writers from New York City, Politicians from New York City, 2020 United States presidential candidates, People from Schenectady, New York, US Democratic Party politicians

Andrew M. Yang (born January 13, 1975) is an American entrepreneur, political commentator and politician. He is the Founder of Venture for America. He was a candidate for President of the United States in the 2020 presidential election. Until 2021, he was a Democrat. Yang ran for Mayor of New York City in the 2021 election. In 2021, he founded the Forward Party.

[[Schenectady, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York, County seats in New York

Schenectady s (ski) is a city in Schenectady County, New York, United States, of which it is the county seat. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 66,135.

[[Tom Benson]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from influenza, Businesspeople from New Orleans, Louisiana, American philanthropists

Thomas Milton Benson (July 12, 1927 – March 15, 2018) was an American businessman, philanthropist and sports franchise owner. He was the owner of the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League (NFL) and New Orleans Pelicans of the National Basketball Association (NBA).

As a sports team owner, Benson had a Super Bowl victory; with the Saints winning Super Bowl XLIV.

Benson died of complications from influenza on March 15, 2018 in Jefferson, Louisiana at the age of 90.

[[Neptune City, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey, Monmouth County, New Jersey

Neptune City is a borough in Monmouth County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the borough's population was 4,869.

The borough borders the Monmouth County municipalities of Avon-by-the-Sea, Bradley Beach and Neptune Township.

[[2009 attack on the Sri Lanka national cricket team]]

CATEGORIES: Terrorist incidents in the 2000s, 2009 in Asia, 21st century in Sri Lanka, 2000s in Pakistan, March events, 2009 crimes

On 3 March 2009, the Sri Lankan national cricket team was attacked in Lahore, Pakistan. Six members of the Sri Lanka national cricket team were injured. Six Pakistani policemen and two civilians were killed.

[[Swiss Life]]

CATEGORIES: 1857 establishments in Europe, Companies of Switzerland, Insurance companies, Zürich

The Swiss Life Group is the largest life insurance company of Switzerland and one of Europe’s leading comprehensive life and pensions and financial solutions providers, with approximately CHF 185 bn of assets under management. The company was founded in 1867 in Zurich as the Schweizerische Lebensversicherungs und Rentenanstalt cooperative, the company entered the Swiss stock market in 1997 and adopted its current name in 2002. In 2015, the group declared a premium income of CHF 18.9 bn, a 5% increase over the previous year. Swiss Life is one of the twenty companies listed under the Swiss Market Index, as SLHN.

[[Keserwan District]]

[[Abu Hanifah]]

CATEGORIES: Muslims, Theologians

Abū Ḥanīfa al-Nuʿmān b. Thābit b. Zūṭā b. Marzubān  (c. September 5, 699 - June 14, 767) was known as Abū Ḥanīfa, or as Imam Abū Ḥanīfa by Sunni Muslims. He was an 8th-century Iraqi Sunni Muslim theologian and jurist. 

Abu Hanifa founded the Hanafi school of orthodox Sunni jurisprudence. This is still the most widely practiced law school in the Sunni tradition. He is often spoken of as al-Imām al-aʿẓam ("The Great Imam") and Sirāj al-aʾimma ("The Lamp of the Imams") in Sunni Islam.

[[Ramosch]]

Ramosch used to be a municipality of the district of Inn in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.  On 1 January 2013 the municipalities of Ramosch and Tschlin joined to become the new municipality of Valsot.

Tschlin used to be a municipality of the district of Inn in the canton of Graubünden in far east Switzerland. On 1 January 2013 the municipalities of Ramosch and Tschlin joined to become the new municipality of Valsot.

[[Third Party System]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century in the United States

The Third Party System is a term of periodization used by historians and political scientists to describe the history of political parties in the United States from 1854 until the mid-1890s, which featured profound developments in issues of American nationalism, modernization, and race.

[[Hexagram]]

CATEGORIES: Symbols, Religious symbols

A hexagram is a six-pointed star, with all lines the same length and all angles the same.  A 'hexangle', 'star hexagon', or 'hexalpha' means the same thing.

It is used in historical, religious and cultural contexts, for example in Hanafism, Judaism, Hinduism and occultism. It is possible that this simple geometric shape, like the triangle, circle, or square, has been created by various peoples with no connection to one another.

Rishi/Ranbir respectively.

[[Perses (Titan)]]

CATEGORIES: Titans

Perses (Πέρσης) was the Titan god of destruction. His parents were Krios and the Okeanid Eurybia. He was a member of the second generation of Titans. His wife was Asteria. Their daughter was Hecate, goddess of magic and witchcraft.

[[Apollo command and service module]]

CATEGORIES: Apollo program, NASA spacecraft

The Apollo command and service module (CSM) was one of two spacecraft, along with the Lunar Module, used for the United States Apollo program which landed astronauts on the Moon. It was built for NASA by North American Aviation. It was launched by itself on three suborbital and low Earth orbit Apollo test missions using the Saturn I launch vehicle. It was also launched twelve times on the larger Saturn V launch vehicle, both by itself and with the Lunar Module. It made a total of nine manned flights to the Moon boosted by the Saturn V.

[[AS-202]]

CATEGORIES: Spaceflight

AS-202 was the second unmanned test flight. It was launched on August 25, 1966. It was the first flight which included the spacecraft guidance and navigation control system, and fuel cells. The success of this flight enabled the Apollo program to send astronauts to space on the next mission, AS 204, also known as Apollo 1.

[[Shahdara]]

CATEGORIES: Delhi

Shahdara is a geographical region in the city of Delhi. It is situated on the banks of Yamuna River. It is one of the oldest localities of Delhi. This region is the headquarters of the newly formed Shahdara district.  

[[Lezgi language]]

CATEGORIES: Caucasian languages, Languages of Azerbaijan

Letzgi (also called Lezgian languag , (Lezgian: Лезги язҍїк, Lezgi iazyk) is a Caucasian language. It is spoken in Dagestan and Azerbaijan. There are about 600,000 speakers. In the Russian part of the territory, Lezgian has the status of an official language, that can be studied at universities. There are also radio programmes using the language. In Azerbaijan, the language has on official status, From 1939 to 1991, it was forbidden to use the language in schools in Azerbaijan. Originally, the language used the Arabic script, but in 1929, this was changed to Cyrillic, like the rest of the Soviet Union.

[[Susch]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Graubünden

Susch (formerly Süs) used to be a municipality of the district of Inn in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

On 1 January 2015 the municipalities of Lavin and Susch became part of the municipality of Zernez.

The Flüela Pass connects Susch with Davos.

[[Tschierv]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Graubünden

Tschierv used to be a municipality of the district of Inn in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

On 1 January 2009 the municipalities of Tschierv, Fuldera, Lü, Müstair, Santa Maria Val Müstair and Valchava joined and became the new municipality of Val Müstair.

[[Forges]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cartoonists, People from Madrid

Antonio Fraguas de Pablo, better known as Forges (17 January 1942 – 22 February 2018) was a Spanish graphic humorist. His artistic name is based on the translation to Catalan of the word "fraguas". He was born in Madrid. He was awarded the Gold Medal for Merit in the Fine Arts, Gat Perich International Humor Award and the Creu de Sant Jordi. He worked for El Jueves, Diario 16, and El País.

Forges died of pancreatic cancer in Madrid on 22 February 2018 at the age of 76.

[[Richard E. Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2018 deaths, Canadian educators, Canadian physicists, People from Alberta, Stanford University faculty

PhysicsRichard Edward Taylor (2 November 1929 – 22 February 2018) was a Nobel Prize–winning Canadian professor emeritus at Stanford University. 

In 1990, he shared the Nobel Prize in Physics with Jerome Friedman and Henry Kendall "for their pioneering investigations concerning deep inelastic scattering of electrons on protons and bound neutrons, which have been of essential importance for the development of the quark model in particle physics."

Taylor died at his home in Stanford, California on 22 February 2018 at the age of 88.

[[Okara, Pakistan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Pakistan

Okara City (اوكاڑا) is the capital of Okara District, Punjab, Pakistan. The name Okara comes from Okaan, the name of a of tree. The city is located southwest of the city of Lahore and Faisalabad is 100 km by passing away Ravi River. It is famous for its and cotton mills. The nearest major city to Okara is Sahiwal. The population of Okara is 326,801. The Multan road connects Okara City with Lahore. 

[[Régis Lacote]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Alumni of the École nationale de l'aviation civile, French businesspeople

Régis Lacote (born 25 April 1972) is a French businessman.

Since February 2018, he is the head of the Orly Airport, replacing Marc Houalla.

Graduate from the ESIEE Amiens (1997) and ENAC (Mastère Spécialisé airport management 1997), he starts his career in 1998 as Head of Safety department of the Roland Garros Airport. He joins Paris Aéroport group in 2002. Since February 2018, he is head of the Orly Airport.

[[Orly Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Airports in France, Buildings and structures in Paris

Orly Airport is a large airport in France.  It is in the outskirts of Paris. In 2017, it handled 32,042,475 passengers.

The head of the airport is Régis Lacote.

[[Gilles de Richemond]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Alumni of the Institut polytechnique des sciences avancées, French engineers

Gilles de Richemond, born the 28th of February 1972, is a French aerospace engineer and businessman. He is the actual Head of IT department of AccorHotels.

Graduate from  Institut polytechnique des sciences avancées (1997), he started his career in 1998 as journalist. In 2004, He joins Canal Plus and Transavia in 2007. He has been Chief of Voyages-sncf.com. He is also a founding member of the « Agile Consortium » France club.

Since December 2017, he is Head of IT of AccorHotels.

[[Cutoff frequency]]

CATEGORIES: Electronics

The cutoff frequency is the minimum frequency that is required for the emission of electrons from a metallic surface, due to incident radiation. Below the cutoff frequency, the phenomenon of the photoelectric effect stops altogether.

When electromagnetic radiation is incident upon a metallic surface, if the radiation has a frequency greater than the threshold frequency, a part of the energy of the incident radiation (known as threshold work function) is absorbed by the electrons on the metallic surface; facilitating electronic excitement. The remaining portion (i.e, energy of incident radiation - threshold work function) is transformed into the kinetic energy of the electrons and accounts for their ejection.

[[MacQueen's bustard]]

CATEGORIES: Birds of Pakistan

MacQueen's bustard (Chlamydotis macqueenii) is a large bird in the bustard family.

[[Tulipa sylvestris]]

CATEGORIES: Plants of Pakistan, Liliaceae, Flowers

Often found in woodlands, Tulip sylvestris is a vigorous, scented, wild tulip. It has bright, buttercup-yellow flowers with a green rib running outside and pointed petals. Flowering in mid-late spring, this tulip is a member of the Botanical Tulips and will happily spread. It is also considered as the "Provincial flower of Balochistan, Pakistan" respectively. 

[[Ringworm]]

CATEGORIES: Fungal diseases

Ringworm is a contagious disease that causes itching of skin. It occurs in small circular red or white patches. Ringworm is one of those diseases that are caused by fungi. It chiefly affects the scalp and feet. Red spots often form on skin called tinea.

[[Pashtun archery]]

CATEGORIES: Sport in Pakistan

Mukha or makha is the traditional Pashtun archery sport played in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan. The game is played with a long arrow (ghashay) and a long bow (leenda). The arrow has a saucer shaped metallic plate (tubray) at its distal end. The archers play in teams and attempt to hit a small white wooden target called takai surrounded by a circular ring called kwaara. The target is secured in fresh clay placed at some height a few meters away from the archer.

[[On the Floor]]

CATEGORIES: 2011 songs, Jennifer Lopez songs, Dance songs, Electro songs

"On the Floor" is a song recorded by American entertainer Jennifer Lopez.  Rapper Pitbull is featured on the song.  It was released on February 22, 2011, as the lead single from Lopez' seventh studio album, Love?  It samples the song "Lambada" by Kaoma. "On the Floor" was later featured as the first track on Lopez' greatest-hits album, Dance Again... the Hits. 

The song has been very successful worldwide, reaching number one in over 13 countries, including Australia, Canada, Germany, New Zealand, and the UK.  In the US, it reached the top three of the Billboard Hot 100.  It was certified triple-platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America for sales of over three million copies in the US. 

The music video for the song has received over 1.1 billion views and over three million likes as of February 2018.

[[Flag of Paraguay]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Paraguay

The flag of Paraguay (bandera de Paraguay) has a horizontal bands of red, white, and blue, defaced on the obverse with the coat of arms of Paraguay, and on the reverse by the reverse side of the arms.

[[Flag of Suriname]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Suriname

The flag of Suriname has a five horizontal bands of green (top, double width), white, red (quadruple width), white, and green (double width). There is a large, yellow, five-pointed star centered in the red band.

[[Flag of Cuba]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Cuba

The national flag of Cuba has five horizontal stripes of blue alternate with white with the red equilateral triangle based on the hoist-side bearing the white five-pointed star in the center.

[[Rorschwihr]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Rorschwihr is a commune in the Haut-Rhin department east France. In 2015, 382 people lived there.

Rorschwihr is at the bottom of Vosges Mountains, between Sélestat and Ribeauvillé.

[[Zernez]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Graubünden

Zernez is a municipality of the district Inn in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland. On 1 January 2015 the former municipalities of Lavin and Susch merged into the municipality of Zernez.

Zernez is a major node in the regional road network, with roads leading into the Upper Engadine and towards Italy, the Lower Engadine and towards Austria, over the Fuorn Pass into the Val Mustair and over the Flüela Pass. Zernez is the center for visitors of the Swiss National Park (Parc Naziunal).

[[Time in Finland]]

CATEGORIES: Time by country, Finland

Finland uses Eastern European Time (EET) (UTC+02:00) in the winter and Eastern European Summer Time (EEST) (UTC+03:00) during the summer. Finland has observed daylight saving time (DST) since 1981 advancing the clock at 03:00 EET on the last Sunday in March and back at 04:00 EET on the last Sunday in October.

[[Time in Arizona]]

CATEGORIES: Time zones, Arizona

Arizona uses Mountain Standard Time (MST) (UTC-07:00). Most of the state does not observe daylight saving time unlike the rest of the United States, except in the Navajo Nation.

[[Sridevi]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Accidental deaths by drowning, Indian movie actors, Indian movie producers

Sridevi Kapoor  (born Shree Amma Yanger Ayyapan; 13 August 1963 – 24 February 2018) was an Indian movie actress and movie producer. She was born in Sivakasi, Madras State, India. She was known for her role in the 2012 movie English Vinglish. In 2013, the Government of India awarded her the Padma Shri, the fourth highest civilian honor

Sridevi died of cardiac arrest in Dubai, United Arab Emirates on 24 February 2018 at the age of 54. Although it was earlier announced that the cause if death was a cardiac arrest, the forensic report released by Dubai Police said that Sridevi died of accidental drowning.

[[Enneadecagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

A enneadecagon or 19-gon is a shape with 19 sides and 19 corners. It is also known as an enneakaidecagon or a nonadecagon.

[[Folco Quilici]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters

Folco Quilici (9 April 1930 – 24 February 2018) was an Italian movie director and screenwriter. He directed a total of 22 movies between 1952 until his retirement in 2005. He was known for directing The Last Paradise, The Wind Blows Free, and The Sixth Continent. He also wrote the script for Dagli Appennini alle Ande. He was born in Ferrara, Italy.

Quilici died in Orvieto, Italy of a stroke on 24 February 2018 at the age of 87.

[[Alexander B. Morrison]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2018 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Canadian scientists, American educators, American Christians, People from Edmonton

Alexander Baillie Morrison (22 December 1930 – 12 February 2018) was a Canadian-born American scientist, academic, and public servant. He was a general authority of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) from 1987 until his death. He was born in Edmonton, Alberta.

Morrison died in Bountiful, Utah on 12 February 2018 at the age of 87.

[[Tridecagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

A tridecagon or trikaidecagon or triskaidecagon or trisdecagon or 13-gon is a shape with 13 sides and 13 corners.

[[Don J. Briel]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from leukemia, American theologians, American Roman Catholics, Writers from California

Donald Jonathan Briel (January 28, 1947 – February 15, 2018) was an American theologian. He was born in Ventura, California. 

Briel held the Blessed John Henry Newman Chair of Liberal Arts at the University of Mary in Bismarck, North Dakota from August 2014 until his death in 2018.

Briel was the founder of the Center for Catholic Studies at the University of St. Thomas in St. Paul, Minnesota. He held the Koch Chair of Catholic Studies and served as Director from 1993 to 2014.

Briel died of leukemia in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 15, 2018 at the age of 71. 

[[Tony Singh]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian songwriters, Living people

Tony Singh is a Canadian alternative rock vocalist and songwriter based in Toronto. Tony was nominated for The Juno award in 1996 and he was awarded the Sikh Centennial Award in 1997 for an album Jmpn For Joy.

[[Gerald Weiß]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2018 deaths, German Olympians

Gerald Weiß (8 January 1960 – 17 February 2018) was an East German javelin thrower. He was born in Lübz, Germany. His personal best throw was 83.30 metres, achieved in June 1988 in Jena. He participated in the 1988 Summer Olympics.

Weiß died in Kloster Lehnin, Germany on 17 February 2018 at the age of 58.

[[Charles Pence Slichter]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, American physicists, Scientists from New York, People from Ithaca, New York

Charles Pence Slichter (January 21, 1924 – February 19, 2018) was an American physicist. He was best known for his work on nuclear magnetic resonance and superconductivity. He was awarded the 2007 National Medal of Science by President George W. Bush.

[[Jiichiro Date]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Wrestlers, People from Ōita Prefecture, Japanese Olympic gold medalists

Jiichiro Date was a Japanese freestyle wrestler. He won the world cup in 1973 and an Olympic gold medal in 1976 and placed third at the 1975 World Championships. He was born in Ōita Prefecture, Japan.

Date died of a heart attack in Tokyo, Japan on 20 February 2018 at the age of 66.

[[Herbert Ehrenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2018 deaths, German politicians

Herbert Ehrenberg (21 December 1926 – 20 February 2018) was a  German politician. He was born in Kollnischken, East Prussia, Weimar Germany. He served as Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs from 1976 through 1982. 

Ehrenberg died in Wilhelmshaven, Germany on 20 February 2018 at the age of 91.

[[Agnieszka Kotulanka]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2018 deaths, Drug-related deaths, Polish movie actors, Polish television actors, People from Warsaw

Agnieszka Kotulanka, rightly Agnieszka Sas-Uhrynowska (born Agniesza Kotuła; 26 October 1956 – 20 February 2018) was a Polish actress and a performer of actress songs. She was known for long-term appearance as Krystyna Lubicz in Polish soap opera Klan (1997-2013). She also appeared as Karska in the 1995 movie Holy Week directed by Andrzej Wajda.

Kotulanka died due to dipsomania in Warsaw on 20 February 2018 at the age of 61.

[[Emma Chambers]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2018 deaths, Actors from Yorkshire, Deaths from myocardial infarction, English movie actors, English television actors, English voice actors

Emma G. M. Chambers (11 March 1964 – 21 February 2018) was an English actress. She was known for playing the role of Alice Tinker in the BBC comedy The Vicar of Dibley and Honey Thacker in the movie Notting Hill (1999).

Chambers died on 21 February 2018 in Lymington, Hampshire of a heart attack at the age of 53.

[[James Laxer]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Canadian economists, Canadian educators, Writers from Montreal, Politicians from Montreal

James Robert Laxer (22 December 1941 – 23 February 2018), also known as Jim Laxer, was Canadian political economist and professor at York University. He was born in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. 

In 1971, Laxer ran for the leadership of the federal NDP and shocked the convention by winning one-third of the vote against party stalwart David Lewis.

In 1981, he was hired as director of research for the federal NDP, but left in controversy in 1983 when he published a report critiquing the party's economic policies as being "out of date".

Laxer died on 23 February 2018 in Paris, France of a suspected heart attack at the age of 76.

[[Shmuel Auerbach]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from cardiovascular disease, Disease-related deaths in Israel, Israeli rabbis, People from Jerusalem

Rabbi Shmuel Auerbach (שמואל אורבך רב) (September 21, 1931 – February 24, 2018) was a Haredi rabbi. He was born in Jerusalem, Israel. He was thought as a leading non-Hasidic Lithuanian posek (halachic authority) for many Haredi Jews in Israel. 

Rabbi Auerbach was the rosh yeshiva of Yeshivas Maalot HaTorah and the Nasi (president) of Yeshivas Midrash Shmuel and Yeshivas Toras Simcha, both in Jerusalem. For a short time, he also served as one of the roshei yeshiva of Yeshivas Itri in Jerusalem.

Rabbi Auerbach died in Jerusalem on February 24, 2018 of heart disease at the age of 86.

[[Óscar Julio Vian Morales]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Guatemalan people, Roman Catholics

Óscar Julio Vian Morales S.D.B. (18 October 1947 – 24 February 2018) was a Guatemalan archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Guatemala from his appointment by Pope Benedict XVI on 2 October 2010 until his death in 2018. He had served as archbishop of Los Altos in Guatemala. He was born in Guatemala City. He was installed as Archbishop of Los Altos on 17 April 2007.

Vian Morales died of cancer on 24 February 2018 in Guatemala City at the age of 70.

[[List of programs broadcast by Disney channel]]

CATEGORIES: Television series by Disney

This is a list of television programs currently broadcast (in first-run or reruns), scheduled to be broadcast or formerly broadcast on Disney Channel, a family-oriented American basic cable channel and former premium channel, owned by The Walt Disney Company. The channel was launched on April 18, 1983, and airs a mix of animated and live-action programming, ranging from action to drama to comedy.

[[Sunan an-Nasai]]

CATEGORIES: Hadith Books

Sunan an-Nasai (Arabic: سنن النسائي‎), also known as Sunan as-Sughra is one of the Kutub al-Sittah (six major hadith collections). It was collected by An-Nasai. Sunnis consider this collection as the third most important of the six major Hadith collections.

[[Flag of Trinidad and Tobago]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Trinidad and Tobago

The flag of Trinidad and Tobago is a red field with a white-fimbriated black diagonal band from the upper hoist-side to the lower fly-side.

[[Flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

The flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines was created in October 1985.

[[Flag of El Salvador]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, El Salvador

The flag of El Salvador was created in 1912. It has two horizontal blue bands at the top and bottom and a white band in the middle with the Coat of arms of El Salvador in the center.

[[Flag of Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Dominica

The flag of Dominica was created in 1978, with some small changes having been made in 1981, 1988, and 1990. The original flag was designed by playwright Alwin Bully in early 1978 as the country prepared for independence.

[[Flag of Grenada]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Grenada

The national flag of Grenada was created in 1974.

[[Flag of Saint Kitts and Nevis]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Saint Kitts and Nevis

The flag of Saint Kitts and Nevis was created in 1983.

[[Flag of South Korea]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, South Korea

The flag of the South Korea, also known as the Taegukgi (also spelled as Taegeukgi, literally "supreme ultimate flag"), has three parts: a white rectangular background, a red and blue Taeguk, symbolizing balance, in its center, and four black trigrams selected from the original eight, one toward each corner.

[[Flag of North Korea]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, North Korea

The flag of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, also known as the Ramhongsaek Konghwagukgi (literally "red-colored flag of the republic"), has a central red panel, bordered both above and below by a narrow white stripe and a broad blue stripe. The central red panel has a five-pointed red star in a white circle near the left side.

[[Mayar Badhon (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television series, 2017 Indian television series debuts

Mayar Badhon is a Bengali television Soap Opera that premiered on May 29, 2017 and airs on STAR Jalsha. It is produced by Surinder Films and stars Jasmin Roy and Debottam Majumdar in lead roles and Nandini Chatterjee as the main antagonist.The Show is Went  Off Air on 17 June 2018 and it  got replaced by Ardhangini

[[Anchiceratops]]

CATEGORIES: Ceratopsids

Anchiceratops was a kind of plant-eating dinosaur. It had a long frill on the back of its head and three horns on its face. There were two long ones above its eyes and one shorter one on its nose. It was similar to Triceratops, which also had these features. Anchiceratops was found in the Horseshoe Canyon Formation, which is a fossil site in Alberta. There is just one species of Anchiceratops, A. ornatus.

[[John Jacob Lavranos]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from stroke, South African people, Portuguese businesspeople, Botanists, Environmentalists

John Jacob Lavranos (29 March 1926 – 1 February 2018) was a South African-Portuguese insurance broker and botanist. He had a special interest in succulents. He was born in Corfu, Greek Island. He settled in Loulé, Portugal a small town near Faro in southern Portugal in 1995 and donated most of his plants to the Gibraltar Botanic Gardens.

Lavranos died in Loulé from a stroke on 1 February 2018 at the age of 91.

[[Gelterkinden]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Basel-Landschaft

Gelterkinden is a municipality of the district of Sissach in the canton of Basel-Landschaft in Switzerland.

[[Müstair]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Graubünden

Müstair was a municipality in Inn in the canton of Graubünden, Switzerland. On 1 January 2009 the municipalities Müstair, Fuldera, Lü, Santa Maria Val Müstair, Tschierv and Valchava joined together to become the new municipality Val Müstair.

The easternmost point of Switzerland, at Piz Chavalatsch, is in the municipality.

The main tourist attraction in the area is the Benedictine Convent of Saint John.

[[Milan Křížek]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2018 deaths, Czech musicians, Czech educators, Violinists

Milan Křížek (mɪlan ˈkr̝̊iːʒɛk; 9 March 1926, Lišov – 15 February 2018, České Budějovice) was a Czech composer, music teacher and viola player. During 1990-2001, Křížek taught the theory of music and composition at the Conservatoire in České Budějovice.

Until 1992 he was also employed as violist in the Opera Orchestra of the South Bohemian Theatre, in the South Czech Philharmonic Orchestra and in several other chamber ensembles.

His works include  Concerto grosso for violin, viola and orchestra (1989), Concerto for 14 string instruments, Sonata for viola solo (1996), Sonatina danzante for flute and clarinet (2000), Seven sequences for clarinet and percussions (2002), Capriccia for soprano, flute, viola and percussion on verses of Konstantin Biebl (2005), Concerto for violin and orchestra (2010), Largo desolato for violin, viola and violoncello (2010) and Collage IV for 3 violoncellos (2012).

Křížek died on 15 February 2018 in České Budějovice, Czech Republic at the age of 91.

[[Valiant (2005)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 movies, English-language movies

Valiant is a 2005 British-American computer-animated movie produced by Vanguard Animation and Odyssey Entertainment, The 45th movie in Walt Disney Studios, and released by Entertainment Film Distributors in the United Kingdom on March 25, 2005 and by Walt Disney Pictures in the United States on August 19, 2005. Set in May of the year 1944, it tells the story of a group of war pigeons during World War II. Reviews of Valiant were mixed. The movie is based on a story by Jordan Katz, George Webster and George Melrod, and inspired by true stories of hundreds of pigeons that helped the soldiers in the war.

[[Jacques Dubochet]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Swiss scientists

Jacques Dubochet (born 8 June 1942) is a retired Swiss biophysicist. He was born in Aigle, Switzerland.

He is a former researcher at the European Molecular Biology Laboratory in Heidelberg, Germany, and an honorary professor of biophysics at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland.

In 2017, he received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry together with Joachim Frank and Richard Henderson "for developing cryo-electron microscopy for the high-resolution structure determination of biomolecules in solution".

[[Wellston, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

Wellston is a city in Ohio in the United States. 5,663 people lived there in the 2010 census. It is in  Jackson County. 

The school district there has four different schools:

[[Rudy Regalado]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from pulmonary embolism, Disease-related deaths in California, Cleveland Indians players, Sportspeople from Los Angeles, California

Rudolph Valentino Regalado (May 21, 1930 - February 12, 2018) was an American Major League Baseball player. He was an infielder for the Cleveland Indians from 1954 to 1956, and played in the 1954 World Series. He was born in Los Angeles, California.

Regalado died on February 12, 2018 in San Diego, California of a pulmonary embolism at the age of 87.

[[Ainsley Gotto]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2018 deaths, Cancer deaths in Sydney, Civil servants, Designers, Australian businesspeople, Writers from Queensland

Ainsley Gotto (14 February 1946 – 25 February 2018) was an Australian public servant and interior designer. She was the private secretary to Prime Minister John Gorton in the late 1960s. She was born in Annerley, Queensland.

Gotto began work as a typist at the Department of Immigration, but left after a few months to work for a private firm. After a year, she returned to government work at the Trade Commission Service.

When Gorton stepped down as prime minister in March 1971, Gotto stayed in his service when he became Minister for Defence, but resigned from the public service in 1972.

Gotto died at a hospital in Woollahra, Sydney of cancer-related complications on 25 February 2018 at the age of 72.

[[Sahlay]]

CATEGORIES: Islam

Sahlay (or Saleh, Salih) was a prophet in Arabia long before the birth of Islam. He has been mentioned in the Quran.

[[Everybody Knows (Leonard Cohen song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 songs, Leonard Cohen songs, Songs written by Leonard Cohen

"Everybody Knows" is a song written by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen and collaborator Sharon Robinson. It has often been covered and used in soundtracks. "Everybody Knows" was first released on Cohen's album I'm Your Man, February 1988.

The lyrics include references to AIDS, social problems, and relationship and religious issues.

A cover of the song by Sigrid plays during the opening credits of Justice League.

[[Popular Problems]]

CATEGORIES: Leonard Cohen albums, 2014 albums

Popular Problems is the thirteenth studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen. It was released on September 19, 2014 in Friday-release countries (such as France and Ireland) and on September 22, 2014 elsewhere.

Most of the songs were new, though Cohen did debut "Born in Chains" onstage in 2010 and "My Oh My" was played during a soundcheck the same year.

Upon its release the album received uniformly positive reviews from critics. The New York Times gave a moderately positive review, calling Cohen "one of rock’s most profound aphorists".

The album peaked at number one on the Canadian Albums Chart, selling 20,000 copies in its first week.

[[You Want It Darker (song)]]

CATEGORIES: Leonard Cohen songs

"You Want It Darker" is a single by Canadian poet and musician Leonard Cohen. It was released on October 21, 2016, three weeks before Cohen's death. The song is the title track from Cohen's album You Want It Darker. 

It earned Cohen a Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance.

[[Various Positions]]

CATEGORIES: Leonard Cohen albums, 1984 albums

Various Positions is the seventh studio album by Leonard Cohen, It was released in December 1984 (and February 1985). It marked not only his turn to the modern sound, but also, after the harmonies and backing vocals from Jennifer Warnes on the previous Recent Songs (1979). The album included Cohen's best known work "Hallelujah".  

Various Positions made the top ten in Spain, Portugal, and Scandinavia, and fared modestly well in the United Kingdom.  In the original 1985 Rolling Stone review, Don Shewey complimented Lissauer's "lucid and beautiful production".

[[Dance Me to the End of Love]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 songs, Leonard Cohen songs, Songs written by Leonard Cohen

"Dance Me to the End of Love" is a 1984 song by Leonard Cohen. It was first performed by Cohen on his 1984 album Various Positions. It has been recorded by many artists and in 2009 was described as "trembling on the brink of becoming a standard." The song has many references to Greek gods.

[[I'm Your Man (Leonard Cohen song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 songs, Leonard Cohen songs, Songs written by Leonard Cohen

"I'm Your Man" is a song written by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen, first released on the album of the same name. Originally released as a single in 1988, it reached number 57 in the French charts after Cohen's death in 2016. "Everybody Knows" was first released on Cohen's album I'm Your Man, February 1988.

Rolling Stone said, "Set to a cheesy drum-machine beat and sotto voce horn riffs, with more than a little suggestion of a country ballad, Cohen conversationally throws himself at the feet of a woman he's done wrong. He'd never beg for her forgiveness, of course. But if he did: 'I'd crawl to you baby and I'd fall at your feet/And I'd howl at your beauty like a dog in heat....'"

[[I'm Your Man (Leonard Cohen album)]]

CATEGORIES: Leonard Cohen albums, 1988 albums

I'm Your Man is the eighth studio album by Leonard Cohen, released in 1988. The album marked Cohen's further move to a more modern sound.

I'm Your Man was recorded in Los Angeles and Montreal and employed four producers: Roscoe Beck, Jean-Michel Reusser, Michel Robidoux, and Cohen himself.

The album includes some of the singer's most popular songs and concert staples, including the single "Ain't No Cure for Love", "First We Take Manhattan", "Tower of Song", and "Everybody Knows", which was a collaboration with Cohen's backup singer Sharon Robinson.

[[First We Take Manhattan]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 songs, Leonard Cohen songs

"First We Take Manhattan" is a song written by Leonard Cohen. It was originally recorded by Jennifer Warnes on her 1986 Cohen tribute album Famous Blue Raincoat, which consisted entirely of songs written or co-written by Cohen.

Ben Hewitt writing for The Guardian in 2015 drew attention to the lyric's apocalyptic nature, imagining Cohen "greedily eyeing world domination like a Bond villain".

Joe Cocker covered "First We Take Manhattan" on his 1999 album No Ordinary World.

[[The Future (Leonard Cohen album)]]

CATEGORIES: Leonard Cohen albums, 1992 albums

The Future is the ninth studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen, released in 1992. Political events and history are found elsewhere on the album, with Cohen making references to Tiananmen Square, Stalin, World War II and Hiroshima.

The title track was originally called "If You Could See What's Coming Next", and underwent extensive rewrites, taking up almost sixty pages in Cohen's notebook, while "Closing Time" took two years with Cohen even starting over from scratch on the song as late as March 1992.

[[Suzanne (Leonard Cohen song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s songs, Leonard Cohen songs, Songs written by Leonard Cohen

"Suzanne" is a song written by Canadian poet and musician Leonard Cohen in the 1960s. First published as a poem in 1966, it was recorded as a song by Judy Collins in the same year. Cohen performed it as his debut single, from his 1967 album Songs of Leonard Cohen. 

In 2006, Pitchfork Media listed the song #41 on their list of "The Top Songs of the 1960s".

[[So Long, Marianne]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 songs, Leonard Cohen songs, Songs written by Leonard Cohen

"So Long, Marianne" is a 1967 song written by Canadian poet and musician Leonard Cohen. It was featured on his debut album, Songs of Leonard Cohen. Pitchfork Media placed it at number 190 on their list of "The 200 Greatest Songs of the 1960s."

[[Songs of Leonard Cohen]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 albums, Leonard Cohen albums

Songs of Leonard Cohen is the debut album by Canadian folk singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen. It was released on December 27, 1967 on Columbia Records. The best known song from the album is "So Long, Marianne".

Songs of Leonard Cohen foreshadowed the kind of chart success Cohen would go on to achieve. It reached number 83 on the Billboard 200 and achieving gold status in the US only in 1989, but peaked at number 13 on the UK Albums Chart, and spent nearly a year and a half on it.

[[Take This Waltz (song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 songs, Leonard Cohen songs

"Take This Waltz" is a song by Canadian singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen. It was originally released as part of the 1986 Federico García Lorca tribute album Poet in New York (Poeta en Nueva York) and as a single.

The song was later included in Cohen's 1988 studio album I'm Your Man. The song's lyrics are a loose translation, into English, of the poem "Pequeño vals vienés" (Little Viennese Waltz) by the Spanish poet Federico García Lorca (one of Cohen's favorite poets). The poem was first published in Lorca's seminal book Poeta en Nueva York. 

The song reached number one in Spain in 1986.

[[Bountiful, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Bountiful is a city in Davis County, Utah, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 42,552, a three percent increase over the 2000 figure of 41,301.

[[Kundo Phooler Mala]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television series, 2017 Indian television series debuts, 2018 television series endings, 2018 disestablishments in India

Kundo Phooler Mala is an Indian Bengali television Soap Opera that premiered on 29 May 2017 at 6:00PM and aired on STAR Jalsha. Produced by Magic Moments Motion Pictures, It started Indrajit Chakraborty and Rukma Roy in lead roles, Debolina Dutta in a negative role and Laboni Sarkar, Sohini Sanyal, Bharat Kaul, Shankar Chakraborty in supporting roles. The Show Went  Off Air on 18 March 2018.

[[Pan-Africanism]]

CATEGORIES: Pan-Africanism

Pan-Africanism is a political movement about improving the position of Africa, and people with ancestors from Africa in the world. Pan-Africanists believe the slave trade and colonialism have hurt African nations and people, and the solution is for Africans to unite politically.

[[Diomedes]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

Diomedes (Διομήδης, Diomēdēs - "God-like cunning, advised by Zeus") was an ancient Greek hero and one of the central figures of the Iliad. Son of King Tydeus and Queen Deipyle, he was the leader of the Argive contingent during the Trojan War. Diomedes was, alongside Greater Ajax, regarded as one of the greatest of all the Achaean warriors, second only to Achilles in terms of prowess.

[[Hexadecagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

An hexadecagon or hekkaidecagon is a shape with 16 sides and 16 corners.

[[Parallelepiped]]

CATEGORIES: Polyhedra

In geometry, a parallelepiped is a three-dimensional figure formed by six parallelograms (the term rhomboid is also sometimes used with this meaning). By analogy, it relates to a parallelogram just as a cube relates to a square or as a cuboid to a rectangle. In Euclidean geometry, its definition encompasses all four concepts (i.e., parallelepiped, parallelogram, cube, and  square). In this context of affine geometry, in which angles are not differentiated, its definition admits only parallelograms and parallelepipeds.  Three equivalent definitions of parallelepiped are

The rectangular cuboid (six rectangular faces), cube (six square faces), and the rhombohedron (six rhombus faces) are all specific cases of parallelepiped.

[[Lulu Belle Madison White]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1957 deaths, American civil rights activists, People from Texas

Lulu (or Lula) Belle Madison White (1900-1957) was a teacher and civil rights activist in Texas during the 1940s and 1950s. In 1939, White was named as the president of the Houston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) before becoming executive secretary of the branch in 1943. Under her leadership, the Houston chapter of the NAACP more than doubled in size from 1943 to 1948.

[[Pulaski, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Pulaski is a city in the U.S. state of Tennessee. It is the county seat of Giles County. 7,870 people lived there in the 2010 census.

[[Flag of Kuwait]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Kuwait

The national flag of Kuwait (علم الكويت) was created in 1961. It has green, white, and red horizontal bands with a black trapezoid next to the left side.

[[Pentacontagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

In geometry, a pentacontagon or pentecontagon or 50-gon is a fifty-sided polygon. The sum of any pentacontagon's interior angles is 8640 degrees.

[[Hexacontagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

A hexacontagon or 60-gon is a shape with 60 sides and 60 corners.

[[Enneacontagon]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

[[Myrmidons]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

The Myrmidons (Μυρμιδόνες, Myrmidones) were a legendary people of Greek mythology. Native to the region of Thessaly, they were said to be the fiercest and strongest of all the warriors in Greece; during the Trojan War, they were led by Achilles, as described in Homer's Iliad. According to Greek myth, they were created by Zeus from a colony of ants, from which their name is derived - Greek myrmex (μύρμηξ), meaning "ant".

[[Umm al-Quwain]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the United Arab Emirates, Emirates of the United Arab Emirates

Umm al-Quwain (أمّ القيوين; ʔumː alˈqajwajn) is a city of the seven sovereign emirates in the United Arab Emirates, in the north of the country.

Umm al-Quwain lies on the Arabian Gulf.

[[Pratidaan]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 Indian television series debuts

Pratidaan (

[[Ursula B. Marvin]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2018 deaths, American astronomers, American geologists, American educators, Scientists from Vermont, Scientists from Massachusetts, People from Burlington, Vermont

Ursula Bailey Marvin (August 20, 1921 – February 12, 2018) was an American planetary geologist and author. She worked for the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory. 

She won the 1997 Lifetime Achievement Award from Women in Science and Engineering. Asteroid (4309) Marvin is named in her honour.

Marvin died at a retirement home in Concord, Massachusetts on February 12, 2018 at the age of 96.

[[Hina Jilani]]

CATEGORIES: Pakistani people

Hina Jilani (حنا جیلانی) (born 1953) is an advocate of the Supreme Court of Pakistan and a human-rights activist from Lahore in Punjab, Pakistan.

[[Special Representative of the Secretary-General]]

CATEGORIES: United Nations

A Special Representative of the Secretary-General is a highly respected expert who has been appointed by the Secretary-General of the United Nations to represent her/him in meetings with heads of state on critical human rights issues. The representatives can carry out country visits to investigate allegations of human rights violations or act as negotiators on behalf of the United Nations.

[[Human Rights Commission of Pakistan]]

CATEGORIES: Pakistan

A Special Representative of the Secretary-General is a highly respected expert who has been appointed by the Secretary-General of the United Nations to represent her/him in meetings with heads of state on critical human rights issues. The representatives can carry out country visits to investigate allegations of human rights violations or act as negotiators on behalf of the United Nations.

[[David Caron]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in London, American educators, Writers from Hartford, Connecticut

David D. Caron (June 28, 1952 – February 20, 2018) was an American professor of law. He was born in Hartford, Connecticut. He did public international law, environmental law, and international arbitration. He was the dean of the King's College, London School of Law, and an emeritus professor of UC Berkeley School of Law.

Caron died on February 20, 2018 in London, England at the age of 65.

[[Government of India Act 1858]]

CATEGORIES: British India, 1858, 1850s in the United Kingdom, 19th century in India

The Government of India Act 1858 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom (21 & 22 Vict. c. 106) passed on August 2, 1858. Its provisions called for the liquidation of the British East India Company (who had up to this point been ruling British India under the auspices of Parliament) and the transference of its functions to the British Crown.

The Act ushered in a new period of Indian history, bringing about the end of Company rule in India. The era of the new British Raj would last until Partition of British India in August 1947, at which time all of the territory of the British Raj was granted Dominion status within the Dominion of Pakistan and the Dominion of India.

[[Government of India Act 1947]]

CATEGORIES: British India, 1947 in Asia, 1947 in the United Kingdom, 1940s in India, 20th century in Pakistan, 1947 in law

The Indian Independence Act 1947 (1947 c. 30 (10 & 11. Geo. 6.)) is an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom that partitioned British India into the two new Independent Dominions of India and Pakistan.  The Act received the royal assent on 18 July 1947, and Pakistan came into being on 14 August and India came into being on 15 August.

[[Boyhood Productions]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television

Boyhood Productions is a productions based in Kolkata. The show has produced three popular shows that air on Star Jalsha. They are Pratidaan, Jiban Jyoti, Bijoyini and Ke Apon Ke Por. The producers of Boyhood Productions are Gurjit Singh, Surinder Singh, and Sushanta Das.

[[Hawaii–Aleutian Time Zone]]

CATEGORIES: Time zones

The Hawaii-Aleutian time zone subtracts ten hours from UTC during standard time (UTC-10) and nine hours during daylight saving time (UTC-9).

This time zone is called Hawaii-Aleutian Standard Time (HST) during standard time (Winter). It is called Hawaii-Aleutian Daylight Time (HDT) during daylight saving time (Summer). 

Places that are in Hawaii-Aleutian Time Zone

United States

-Hawaii (No DST)

-Alaska (Western Aleutian Islands west of 169.5 degrees W)

France

Most of french polynesia.

[[Classical crossover]]

CATEGORIES: Popular culture, Music genres

Classical crossover is a style of music where classical music is performed in a popular modern style that is different to how that music was originally performed. It can also refer to popular performers who normally play rock music or other popular music, but adapt their music into a classical music style like Orchestral music. There are other performers who take Classical repertoire and perform it in modern styles like rock or dance music. One example of this is the band called "Classical Made Modern".

[[Kogo language]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of Africa, Cameroon

Kogo, also called Bakoko and Basoo, is a Bantu language. It is spoken in Cameroon. North and South Kogo are as different from each other as they are from Basaa. They might be three dialects of one language.

[[Giorgi Maisashvili]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Politicians from Georgia (country), Economists, Human rights activists

George (Gia) Maisashvili (გიორგი გია მაისაშვილი) (November 24, 1962 – February 26, 2018) was a Georgian economist, human rights activist and politician. He was a presidential candidate in the Georgian presidential election of 2008. He was born in Tbilisi.

After the Georgian Civil War and the overthrowing of the democratically elected government by Eduard Shevardnadze in 1992, Maisashvili was forced to flee the country and was granted a political asylum by the United States.

Maisashvili died in Tbilisi on February 26, 2018 of colorectal cancer at the age of 55.

[[Amtrak Cascades]]

CATEGORIES: Amtrak, Rail transport in the United States

The Amtrak ''Cascades'' is a passenger train in the United States and Canada. It goes up and down the Pacific Northwest, from Vancouver to Seattle to Portland to Eugene, Oregon. It takes its name from the Cascade Mountains.

The train is run by Amtrak and gets money from Washington and Oregon. It stops in 18 cities. The Cascades name started being used in 1998; trains were already running under different names.

[[James Colby]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2018 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Massachusetts

James Leo Colby (September 20, 1961 – February 23, 2018) was an American actor. Colby appeared in many Broadway plays and few stage productions in Connecticut. 

Colby was known for his roles The Pacemaker (1997), Tower Heist (2011), Safe (2012), The Amazing Spider-Man 2 (2014) and in Patriots Day (2016). In television, he was known for his role as Sergeant Ray Dwyer in Chicago P.D. and Burleson in Empire.

Colby died on February 23, 2018 at the age of 56. 

[[Isosceles triangle]]

CATEGORIES: Polygons

In geometry, an isosceles triangle is a triangle that has two sides of equal length. Sometimes it is specified as having two and only two sides of equal length, and sometimes as having at least two sides of equal length, the latter version thus including the equilateral triangle as a special case.

Examples of isosceles triangles include the isosceles right triangle, the golden triangle, and the faces of bipyramids and certain Catalan solids.

The mathematical study of isosceles triangles dates back to ancient Egyptian mathematics and Babylonian mathematics. Isosceles triangles have been used as decoration from even earlier times, and appear frequently in architecture and design, for instance in the pediments and gables of buildings.

The two equal sides are called the legs and the third side is called the base of the triangle. The other dimensions of the triangle, such as its height, area, and perimeter, can be calculated by simple formulas from the lengths of the legs and base.

Every isosceles triangle has an axis of symmetry along the perpendicular bisector of its base. The two angles opposite the legs are equal and are always acute, so the classification of the triangle as acute, right, or obtuse depends only on the angle between its two legs.

Microblogging is a blog which is typically smaller in file size. It  "allows users to exchange small elements of content such as short sentences, individual images, or video links",

[[Makkal Needhi Maiam]]

CATEGORIES: Political parties in Tamil Nadu, 2018 establishments in India

Makkal Needhi Maiam (Translation: People's Justice Centre), is a indian political party in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. It was founded by famous actor Kamal Haasan. This party was started (launched) in a public meeting at Madurai in 2018 February 21. He also launched his party flag in the meeting. The flag has a symbol with six hands locked with one another. This symbol represents the co-operation between the South Indian states (5 States and 1 Union Territory).

[[Search algorithm]]

CATEGORIES: Searching and sorting algorithms

A search algorithm is a method for finding a target value within a list. It checks each element of the list for the target value until a match is found or until all the elements have been searched.

Linear search is rarely practical because other search algorithms and schemes, such as the binary search algorithm and hash tables, allow significantly faster searching for all but short lists.

[[World of Coca-Cola]]

The World of Coca-Cola is a museum about the history of Coca-Cola, the world's most popular soft drink, and the company who makes it, The Coca-Cola Company.

The museum is in the city of Atlanta, Georgia and opened on May 24, 2007. It covers an area of 20.

[[Penny Vincenzi]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2018 deaths, British novelists, British writers, People from Bournemouth

Penelope Vincenzi (Hannaford, 10 April 1939 – 25 February 2018) was a British novelist. She was born in Bournemouth, England.

She wrote 17 novels and 2 collections of stories. Her sales by 2014 amounted to over 7 million copies.

She started work for the Daily Mirror as a secretary, and after a year was working for Marjorie Proops, she knowing of her journalistic ambitions, let her help with research and small tasks.

Vincenzi was also a fashion journalist, she worked for various publications, including the Daily Mirror and Vogue.

Vincenzi died on 25 February 2018, aged 78.

[[Flag of Jordan]]

The flag of Jordan was created in 1928, is based on the flag of the Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire during World War I.

[[Flag of Iraq]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Iraq

The flag of Iraq (علم العراق) has three horizontal bands of red, white, and black, charged with the ar (ar, "God is the greatest") in green Kufic script, centered on the white stripe.

The flag of Yemen (علم اليمن) has three horizontal tricolour of red, white and black.

The Arab Liberation Flag served as the inspiration for the flags of both North and South Yemen prior to unification, as well as for the current flags of Egypt, Iraq, Sudan, and Syria.

[[Flag of Qatar]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Qatar

The flag of Qatar (علم قطر) is in the ratio of 11:28. It has a white band on the hoist-side, separated from a maroon area on the fly-side by nine white triangles which act as a serrated line. It was adopted on 9 July 1971.

[[Social Democratic Party of Switzerland]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Switzerland, Political parties in Europe, Social democratic parties, 1888 establishments in Europe, 19th century establishments in Switzerland

The Social Democratic Party of Switzerland (also rendered as Swiss Socialist Party; Sozialdemokratische Partei der Schweiz, SP; Parti socialiste suisse, PS; Partito Socialista Svizzero; Partida Socialdemocrata de la Svizra) is a political party in Switzerland. It is represented by two Federal Councilors since 1960 and got the second-most votes in the 2015 national elections.

The party was founded on 21 October 1888, and is currently the second largest of the four leading coalition political parties in Switzerland. It is the only left-wing party with representatives in the Swiss Federal Council. It is also the second largest political party in the Swiss parliament. The current members in the Swiss Federal Council are: Alain Berset and Simonetta Sommaruga.

The SP is the largest pro-European party in Switzerland and supports Swiss membership of the European Union, unlike most other Swiss parties. Additionally, it is strongly opposed to capitalism and maintains a long-term goal of "overcoming capitalism." The party is a member of the Progressive Alliance, and an associate member of the Party of European Socialists.

[[Graveyard slot]]

CATEGORIES: Time, Television

A graveyard slot is a timeslot during the early morning hours, between 2:00 to 6:00 a.m., after late night television and before morning news shows. Many people are sleeping at home, or in work away from the television. The timeslot mainly shows reruns of original shows. Overnight news programs are broadcasted on ABC and CBS. NBC had its overnight news program during the 1980s.

[[VV Cephei]]

CATEGORIES: Red giants, Binary stars, Variable stars, Supergiants

VV Cephei is a eclipsing binary star in the Cepheus constellation. It is 5,000 light years from Earth. 

VV Cephei A is one of the largest known stars, being a red supergiant. Its diameter is 1,475 times that of the Sun. It is orbited by VV Cephei B, a blue star with 1325 times the Solar radius. If VV Cephei A were placed in the center of our Solar System, its radius would reach past the orbit of Jupiter. Nevertheless, stars like WOH G64 and Stephenson 2-18 are larger still.

[[Eudoros]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

In Greek mythology, Eudoros (Εὔδωρος) was one of the Myrmidons as well as the second of five commanders who served under Achilles during the Trojan War. He was a demigod, son of Hermes and Polymele.

[[Phoenix (Myrmidon)]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

In Greek mythology, Phoenix ( Φοῖνιξ, Phoinix; gen. Φοίνικος, Phoinikos) was one of the Myrmidons (Achilles' five commanders during the Trojan War). His parents were Amyntor and Cleobule. He was the king of the Dolopes. He also took part in the hunt for the Calydonian Boar.

[[Swedesboro, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 establishments in the United States, Boroughs in New Jersey

Swedesboro is a borough in Gloucester County, New Jersey, United States. As of 2010, it had a population of 2,584 inhabitants and a population density of 1,292 people per km².

Swedesboro was formed as a borough by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on April 9, 1902, from portions of Woolwich Township. The borough was named for its early settlers originally from the colony of New Sweden.

[[Leo Falcam]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2018 deaths, Presidents of the Federated States of Micronesia, Vice presidents

Leo Ammy Falcam (November 20, 1935 – February 12, 2018) was a Micronesian politician. He was born in Pohnpei. He served as the first elected Governor of Pohnpei from 1979 to 1983 and as Vice President of Micronesia from May 1997 to May 1999. 

Falcam then served as the fifth president of the Federated States of Micronesia from May 11, 1999 to May 11, 2003. In March 2003 he lost his parliamentary seat during elections, denying him a chance at a second term.

Falcam died on February 12, 2018 at the age of 82.

[[Luciano Benjamín Menéndez]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Argentine politicians, Military people, Murderers

Luciano Benjamín Menéndez (19 June 1927 – 27 February 2018) was a former Argentine general and convicted human rights violator and murderer. He served as Commander of the Third Army Corps from 1975 to 1979. He played a prominent role as a murder of social activists. He ordered mass arrests of hundreds of trade union members, students, teachers, journalists and anyone else suspected of collaborating with left-wing guerrillas.

[[Jayendra Saraswathi]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Indian people, Spiritual teachers

Jagadguru Sri Jayendra Saraswathi Shankaracharya (born Subramanyam Mahadeva ; 18 July 1935 – 28 February 2018) was an Indian guru. He was the 69th Shankaracharya Guru and head or pontiff (Pïțhādhipati) of the  Kanchi Kamakoti Peetham. He served as head from 22 March 1954 until his death in 2018. He was born in Irulneeki, Thanjavur dt, Tamil Nadu.

Saraswathi died at a hospital in Kamakshi, India of respiratory failure on 28 February 2018 at the age of 82.

[[Holladay, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Holladay is a city in Salt Lake County, Utah, United States. It is part of the Salt Lake City, Utah Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 26,472 at the 2010 census.

It was reported in the 1990 census as the Holladay-Cottonwood CDP.

[[Memnon (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: People in Greek mythology

Memnon ( Μέμνων) was an Aethiopian king and an ally of the Trojans during the Trojan War. He was a demigod, the son of Tithonus and Eos, the goddess of the dawn. As a warrior, he was considered to be almost Achilles' equal in prowess and skill. During the Trojan War, Memnon himself slew Antilochus in the middle of a fierce battle and was himself later killed by Achilles. The death of Memnon appears to echo that of Hector, another defender of Troy whom Achilles had also slain.

[[Udaipur]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in India, Settlements in Rajasthan

Udaipur, also called the "City of Lakes" or the "Kashmir of Rajasthan," is a major city, municipal corporation and the administrative headquarters of the Udaipur district in the Indian state of Rajasthan. It is the historic capital of the kingdom of Mewar in the former Rajputana Agency. It was founded in 1553 by Maharana  Udai Singh of the Sisodia clan of Rajput, when he shifted his capital from the city of Chittorgarh to Udaipur.

[[Torcuato Benjumeda]]

CATEGORIES: 1836 deaths, 1757 births, Architects, People from Cádiz

Torcuato José Benjumeda y Laguada (El Puerto de Santa María,  1757 — Cádiz, 1836) was a Spanish architect. He was a follower of Torcuato Cayón. He was one of the most important neoclassical architects of Andalucia.

[[Namchi]]

Namchi or Namtse is the capital of South Sikkim district, Sikkim.

[[Tamizhaga Vazhvurimai Katchi]]

CATEGORIES: Political parties in Tamil Nadu

Tamizhaga Vazhvurimai Katchi is a political party in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. It was founded by former PMK MLA Panruti T. Velmurugan. This is one of the emerging political parties in Tamil Nadu. The party organizes various struggles for the public related issues.I

[[T. Velmurugan]]

CATEGORIES: Tamil Nadu politicians, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

T. Velmurugan is a Tamil Nadu politician . He is a former Member of the Legislative Assembly of the state. He was elected to the Tamil Nadu legislative assembly as a Pattali Makkal Katchi candidate from Panruti constituency in 2001, and 2006 elections. He is often considered to be Tamil Nationalist. He is the founder of the party Tamizhaga Vazurimai Katchi (TVK).

[[Python (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: Greek legendary creatures

In Greek mythology, Python (Πύθων) was a large serpent or dragon. She was said to live at the center of the Earth, believed by the ancient Greeks to be at Delphi. Her mother was Gaia (Mother Earth). She was killed by the god Apollo.

[[Kathrine Switzer]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people

Kathrine Virginia "Kathy" Switzer (born January 5, 1947, in Amberg, Germany) is an American marathon runner. In 1967, she was the first woman to run in the Boston Marathon as runner #261. During the race, a race official tried to stop her and take her number away. Switzer's boyfriend Thomas Miller pushed the official to the ground. Switzer finished the race.

In 2017, Switzer ran in the Boston marathon again as number 261 on the 50th anniversary of her first run.

[[Piedmont, California]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Alameda County, California, Cities in California, Cities in the San Francisco Bay Area, Enclaves

Piedmont is a small, mostly-residential, semi-suburban city located in Alameda County, California, United States. Piedmont is completely surrounded by the city of Oakland.

[[Caduceus]]

CATEGORIES: Greek mythology

The caduceus (cādūceus; from κηρύκειον, kērykeion) is the staff of the messenger god Hermes in Greek mythology. It is also called the "herald's wand". The caduceus appeared as a golden staff with wings and a pair of serpents wrapped around it.

[[Eurybia (mythology)]]

CATEGORIES: Greek mythology

In Greek mythology, Eurybia (Εὐρυβία or Εὐρυβίη - "of wide force") was a daughter of Gaia and Pontus. She was the wife of the Titan Krios. Their children were Astraeus, Perses, and Pallas.

Tajikistan sent people  to compete at the 2018 Winter Paralympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.  Two people will be competing in para-Nordic skiing in Tajikistan's first appearance at the Winter Paralympics.  They trained in Germany and China before the start of the Games.

[[Dance Again]]

CATEGORIES: Dance-pop songs, Jennifer Lopez songs, 2012 songs

"Dance Again" is a song recorded by American entertainer Jennifer Lopez.  It features Cuban-American rapper Pitbull.  The song was released as the lead single from Lopez' first greatest-hits album, Dance Again... the Hits, on April 2, 2012.  The song was produced by RedOne, who also produced Lopez' and Pitbull's collaboration "On the Floor".

The song has reached the top ten in Austria, Belgium, Spain, Finland, Italy, and Canada and the top twenty in countries like the US, Germany, New Zealand. and the UK.
